item.name: 12 Realms
item.comment: This game is the poster child for "Play before you pay." We bought it thinking the theme sounded cool. But the components are rather sub-par. It comes with miniatures but no bases for them to stand on so you'll have to buy your own. No minis representing villains just tiny cardboard chits unless you buy the expansion. The game boards, one for each realm (and by the way this game only comes with 4 despite what the name of the game leads you to believe) are flimsy. The rule book doesn't layout the game play in any consistent way. And the FAQ serves as the designers trying to be comedians instead of actually answering any questions. We say avoid it.

item.name: 51st State
item.comment: Loving this one so far. Easy play even with all the actions, icons and scoring options. It just flows really well. Nice artwork to boot. There is a bit of a learning curve for the first few games we think. But that hurdle is easily jumped once you get the game pacing and actions down pat. It is at its heart a resource management game and a fun one to boot.

item.name: Above and Below
item.comment: We have owned both Agents of SMERSH and Tales of the Arabian Nights. Let's be honest and call a spade a spade. Tales of the Arabian Nights is not a game. It is a choose your own adventure book trying its best to look like a game by adding a board and dice. SMERSH does a bit of a better job by making it a co-op and adding just a touch of strategy & tactics. But Above and Below delivers on what most people believed they were getting with those games. Ryan Laukat gives you an actual GAME to go with the storytelling. Worker placement and resource management are key to this game. And there is a very good amount of strategy to it. Gaining resources gets you more money which allows you to build buildings and more workers to get you more points at the end of the game. The exploration action which is where the storytelling comes in is whimsical (written by Ryan and his friends and family) but makes you plan ahead. You need workers to explore successfully. This game only gets a nine because the stories are not as engaging or immersive as they are in Arabian Nights or SMERSH. It more than makes up for that with the game mechanisms but if the stories had a bit more meat to them this game might make it into our top 10.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: This game just isn't for us. It gets lots of hype from reviewers because of the theme. But to us it just isn't there. Sure the components look good but so much of it seems to be a random luck fest. Plus there is the whole memory aspect where in the first section of the game you look at tiles to try and determine where you can step safely in a later part of the temple. I HATE memory games. So that was an almost instant turn off for me. But beyond that the game play isn't immersive or engaging. So this one is a pass.

item.name: Age of War
item.comment: A Knizia, abstract, pasted-on-theme filler for sure. But you know what? It works. You roll dice to match symbols on a group of cards that you are both vying for. Collect sets of cards to get more points and whoever has the most points when all the cards are collected wins. A quick, fun filler.

item.name: Agents of SMERSH
item.comment: Fun storytelling game with some good roles and dice chucking. A blast to play with friends but serious gamers need not apply. We don't recommend it for less than three players however.

item.name: Akrotiri
item.comment: Small box with lots of Analysis Paralysis included. It seems simple. Just place a tile onto the table to expand the island chain around Akrotiri. But ... as the area grows larger and larger and you attempt to place temples among those islands (place six temples and you win) the choices become very wide and varied. Temples are placed according to resource locations on map cards you purchase. As more resources get placed through more tiles being played more options become available for placing temples. So very often you end up staring at the tile in your hand and at all the other tiles already placed trying to figure out if after placing that tile you can place your next temple. What starts out very simple soon becomes a brain burning puzzle. So beware ... it may be a small box. But it is not a small game.

item.name: Alea Iacta Est
item.comment: We have a number of dice games in our collection and this one ranks as one of the best. You roll the dice then using sets, straights, etc you assign them to get tiles related to provinces, laws or patricians. Then you begin the set collection. However, you only get one use of the dice each turn. So while you might think getting that Britannia province will score the most, if you let that patrician for Germania go your opponents might just take it. The set collection is really quite simple but gives you a bit to think about. An easy yet strategic game.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: The ultimate gateway game. It doesn't get any more fun or simple than this. Three simple actions each turn. Take cash from the bank, buy a building for your Alhmabra or rearrange buildings already in your Alhambra. That's it. But there is a good amount of strategy in this game mixed with the luck of the card draws from the bank. Heavy Eurogamers might think this is too simple and they are probably right. But it is still so much fun. This game ties Ticket to Ride for our favorite gateway game. It is that good.

item.name: Alhambra: The Dice Game
item.comment: We had been staring at this one of the shelf of our friendly neighborhood gaming store for months but were indecisive because there was nothing really about it anywhere review or gameplay wise. So we finally just said to heck with it and bought it. It took us a while to figure out what to do. The rules are , oddly enough, not written very well which is extremely strange given how easy to follow the rules are for Alhambra and Granada (also by Dirk Henn). So we had to slog through the first game trying to decipher what everything meant. The scoring was weird and , again, not explained very well. We were also perplexed by one thing in the game but found out that wasn't a design mistake. Each round we rolled the dice to see which building we would try and go for but kept getting confused about the allocation until we suddenly realized that our copy had come with 9 white building dice instead of the standard 8. We finally managed to get it sorted out and enjoy the game. It would actually rate close to Alhambra but that rule book just drags it into 7. And if you have Alhambra (and why wouldn't you) it doesn't make a lot of sense to get this one as well.

item.name: Alhambra: The Magical Buildings
item.comment: This expansion is very good and adds an interesting little dimension to the game. The buildings are viewed from on high meaning they can be placed in any direction in your Alhambra.

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment: Kingsburg with a sci-fi theme? Well, you're pretty close but also a bit far off with that description . There are a few differences that make it a whole different bird. Yes. You still allocate resources to build up your particular kingdom/empire. But the worker (dice) placement here can be much more cutthroat. You can very often get blocked out of what you really wanted and have no real recourse. In this game you have the Alien Artifact location which allows you to get cards with certain abilities that can really swing things in your direction. Except for the Leader cards that come with To Forge a Realm there isn't anything like that in Kingsburg. This one also has the ability to hugely mess with your opponent in a fashion other than just taking the stuff they wanted. The Raider's Outpost is certainly very close to an attack option but there are ways to mitigate it. The biggest difference of course is the area control aspect of the game. This not only determines the scoring, it gives you awesome abilities later on though other players can battle it out with you for them. All in all Alien Frontiers is an awesome game. Had we not already owned Kingsburg this game might rate a 10 but we so love Kingsburg that its hard to place this complex sibling higher.

item.name: Amerigo
item.comment: By far the biggest Feld game out there. Why the big box? Well it does at least keep you from having to take that cube tower apart before and after every play. But that's beside the point. Amerigo is one of Feld's best. He takes a mechanism ( the cube tower ) and puts it to an entirely different use than in other games that call upon the same devise. Each turn cubes go in and cubes come out. What color cubes come out and how many determine what actions can be done. The cube tower is an excellent way to determine actions in a game like this where there are so many things you want to do to get the points you need to win the game but typically not enough time to get them in. Instead of relying on dice rolls like some of his other games you get the ability to do a variety of actions as the tower allows. Want to be able to build that last plot on your island to complete it and get the points? All you need is for one cube of that color (green) to come out and chances are you might get to do what you want even if the vast majority of the cubes that come out are for building cannons (black). This game can bring out the AP at times especially when you get to the "Tetris" portion of the game trying to fill out your islands with the building tiles. But that doesn't detract from the way the game plays and the playful mechanism of the cube tower.

item.name: Ancient Terrible Things
item.comment: The 1st game we ever Kickstarted after seeing a preview by the Dice Tower's Ryan Metzler. A game of dice rolling and set collection with a theme steeped in a sort of classic horror/jungle trek style. The components for this are awesome though we got the cool dice and player mats through the Kickstarter stretch goals so whether they will come with the game if/when it reaches stores is debatable. We wish the theme was a bit more tied to the mechanics. But it is an overall fun game that is beautiful when it's all laid out on the table.

item.name: The Ancient World
item.comment: The art was good (all of Ryan Lauket's art designs are fabulous regardless of what game it is) but there was just a lot of fiddliness with this game. The order of the worker placement mattered in conjunction with the number on the worker. The resources were honestly too tight. Plus it never felt like there was the opportunity to get the things done you wanted. I expect worker placement games to be tight but with this is just seems there is too much you need to do in order to get ahead but never the opportunity to do them. When we backed this on Kickstarter it didn't seem like this was the case in the overview for the campaign. Not sure if the rules changed with the finished product or if we were just reading into it wrong. But it was a pass for us.

item.name: Anima: Shadow of Omega
item.comment: We can see where FF was trying to go with this. Put an RPG into a card game. Alas with fiddly rules & lackluster components it just couldn't do what Paizo succeeded in doing with Pathfinder. The art was fantastic. The game itself was just no good.

item.name: Archaeology: The Card Game
item.comment: This is as simple as set collection gets. Collect artifacts from the dig then sell them to the museum. It is fiendishly simple but fun to play. Though I don't think the wife liked our first play as much as I did since I managed to play 7 of the 8 thief cards on her.

item.name: Arctic Scavengers
item.comment: This one is a little hard to pin down. As a deck-builder it suffers a little from having not as many choices as you get from others like Thunderstone. And the clunky combat system in it gets confusing pretty fast.

item.name: Arena: Roma II
item.comment: Stefan Feld hits a home run with this 2-player game. Easy mechanics as well as a lot of take that in a head to head two-player game using dice as its main mechanism. You roll the dice and use them to either get cards into your hand, get money to play those cards from your hand or activate cards already on the table. The game can get cutthroat and nasty at times with cards that make your opponent lose cards, victory pints or money. Plus you are always looking for ways to destroy the cards your opponent has on the table. And with two different end game options : ending a round with more victory points than your foe after all the VP chits have been picked up from the supply or to just run your opponent out of victory points. If you like 2-player games this is the one for you.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment: Massive footprint? Yes A ton of rules that you have to wrestle to the ground? Indeed. More components that you can shake a stick at? Confirmed. 3 hour plus game play? You got it. An immersive world in which you can explore the horror and grandeur of the works of HP Lovecraft? That's what this game is all about. Arkham Horror should be in the top 5 of the themed rankings if you ask us (which you probably aren't. No worries). We don't think there are too many more games that "put you there" like AH does.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Dunwich Horror Expansion
item.comment: Arkham Horror continues to expand and pull you in with this expansion. Can you face the Dunwich Horror and live? Probably not. But at least you'll have fun trying.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Innsmouth Horror Expansion
item.comment: Just when you think things can't get any worse for you. Welcome to Innsmouth. The terror and the gameplay escalate more and more. Will you close the gates in time? Can you stop the Deep Ones from rising? Or will you just end up as a snack for a shuggoth? It happened. LOL. Never get caught and put in jail in Innsmouth. You'll pay the consequences.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Kingsport Horror Expansion
item.comment: Not just gates to other worlds but roaming vortexes that spew monsters and escalate the Great Old Ones' machinations even further. But for once you get a little help from the otherworldly sources. It's not enough in the end (usually). But still an awesome expansion.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Miskatonic Horror Expansion
item.comment: Miskatonic Horror expands all the expansions. Just when you thought no other horrors could crawl their way out of the depths of Arkham. You're wrong! Here they come! Run!

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Curse of the Dark Pharaoh Expansion (Revised Edition)
item.comment: Roaming the streets of Arkham are ancient secrets that could aid you in your quest against the Great Old Ones or spell your doom. This is a must have as it amps up the theme even if just added to the base game.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The King in Yellow Expansion
item.comment: Ok. This is one expansion we could do without. In this case the play isn't the thing as the King in Yellow just makes it much harder for you without really adding anything to the experience.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Lurker at the Threshold Expansion
item.comment: This expansion is a 50/50 for us. The relationship cards add something a little extra to your quest but the main module is just asinine really as you would have to be (literally) insane to use it. This expansion you can probably do without.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment: Yep. We've picked up yet another deck builder. It may be our favorite type of game (possibly tied with worker-placement). The theme is a little bit thin and the artwork is so abstract as to be ugly. It works like your standard deck builder but there is one mechanic we don't care for. To one side is a "cultist" card with only 2 defense that doesn't move from his position that you are allowed to attack should you have nothing else you can attack in the center display. Honestly you could simply hammer away at that guy throughout the game and possibly win just like that. Not to mention this has some of the WORST artwork in board gaming. It's kinda hard to look at really.

item.name: Atlantis Rising
item.comment: This one is tough. Too tough. The theme is great as it reminds us of Disney's "Atlantis : The Lost Empire." The push your luck element of the worker placement is certainly unique. But those Athenians & Misfortune cards are SO punishing. They hit you hard and trying to mitigate them is just as painful. In all the games we played we never even came close to winning. It is brutal. We like challenge in co-ops but when it honestly seems it is impossible to win that takes all the fun out it.

item.name: AttrAction
item.comment: Tossing hematite magnets about on a table doesn't seem like it would be a great amount of fun. But you are wrong if you think so.

item.name: Augustus
item.comment: Ancient Rome is my favorite era in history. But until now we haven't been able to find any Roman themed games that looked good for us. This one is a great game. Granted it is just Bingo! with a Roman theme pasted on (that's the only thing keeping this one from being a 10) but it is so much fun. Shouting "Ava Caesar!" instead of "Bingo!" just adds to it. This one is certainly staying with us.

item.name: Barbarossa
item.comment: Art ... awesome. Game play ... mediocre deck-building that has a few too many moving parts for this type of game. Theme ... WTF?! Look, I like anime. But what in the world were they thinking with this theme. Scantily clad Nazi bimbos? Is this a deck-building game or a sexploitation film?

item.name: Batman Fluxx
item.comment: Nothing about this version of Fluxx grabbed our attention. While the art is based on Batman : The Animated Series ( a show that I love) , it is an art style that lends itself to animation only. It just doesn't look good as still art. Plus the game play is plodding whereas we usually find Fluxx to be fast paced. Plus there is a meta-card in the game that gets you a benefit if you're wearing a Bat-logo shirt! I hate stuff like that in games. It's why we hate party games. Another miss for Fluxx.

item.name: Battle Cry
item.comment: To be honest this game is as good as the games that followed it. The first to use the Commands & Colors system (begging the question why it isn't called the Battle Cry system) it plays just as easy and flawlessly as Memoir '44 and BattleLore. The problem is its limited game play. You can buy enough Memoir '44 modules that chances are you may never play them all. Plus the original BattleLore has plenty of content too and BattleLore 2.0 is coming out with new additions all the time. But Battle Cry just has the scenarios that come in the box (sans fan additions) so it runs of out replayabilty pretty quickly. It is odd that this game died the way it did. It was even given an anniversary edition but still no new content. If this game did have the kind of content that Memoir did we might be hard pressed to decide which one to keep. But with Battle Cry's limited content , Memoir '44 wins that challenge hands down.

item.name: BattleLore (Second Edition)
item.comment: This game suffers from the same liability for us as Battle Cry. We really don't need more than one Commands & Colors game. Granted this one is getting the content added to it on a regular basis thanks to Fantasy Flight. As much as we like fantasy, we prefer the real world scenarios of Memoir '44. Plus the way the combat in addition to the magic works , BattleLore 2.0 doesn't flow as easily in game play as Memoir. But if you like skirmish combat and you are a fantasy fan this is certainly the C&C game for you.

item.name: Battue: Storm of the Horse Lords
item.comment: Yes. The game looks cool. The art on the tiles is certainly unique. And the theme is original. Mongols conquering what appears to be a Roman city. Even the exploration of the tiles to conquer them is very cool. However, when it is all said and done, the game comes down to rolling dice. You can try to mitigate that by sending in more troops but even then you can still be beaten by the dice rolling. Now were the combat in this deterministic combined with card play that might work. But the randomness of the dice just ruin the game in our opinion.

item.name: Battue: The Walls of Tarsos
item.comment: Not much in this expansion really. It just adds more of what you got in the base game.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: I feel like I am just going to be repeating what every one else says about this game. It could be SO GOOD but the Haunt can clutch up this game so bad and so fast. The first half of the game is the best part. You explore the house entering rooms where God only knows what terrors lie in store for you. Cards and tiles give you such flavor text that you cannot help but be drawn into the theme. But once the Haunt happens all that tends to fall by the way side. There are so many ways the game can go and there's no way to know if the game play will continue to work or if it will just break on you right then and there. Plus the haunt can happen so quickly in the right situation that any exploration of the house stops dead robbing the players of what almost everyone universally agrees is the best aspect of the game. Plus let's be honest ... the components are not great. Those character boards are a joke, the card stock is not good and those minis are atrocious. If some one can just fix the second half of the game it might go way up in all gamers' estimation

item.name: Blueprints
item.comment: Blueprints is a moderately strategic dice-building game with some easy mechanics but fun game play. Drawing the dice from the bag to build up your blueprint feels pretty cool and gives you a sense of accomplishment. The drawbacks that keep it at the current rating ? 1) The rule book is not very well written. We had to check BGG forums quite often to sort it all out. And for a small game like this that's kind of inexcusable. 2) There are just too many ways to score for such a small game. You score for the different kinds of dice, you score for the blueprint, you score for the prizes, you score for majority in a certain material. That just seems like complexity for complexity's sake. Despite these it is still a good filler. Check it out.

item.name: Bora Bora
item.comment: Certainly one of Feld's heavier games. In this one you once again use dice to carry out actions. But then the number on the dice make a difference for how well you can carry out those actions. And there are a lot of actions to take; Building huts, gathering resources, laying out shrines, appeasing the gods, hiring locals for work ,etc. There is a lot to do and you can even block other players out of actions by using the dice set at certain values. On top of that every round you will be trying to fulfill the demands of scoring tiles that become available each and every round. You may only have a certain number at the end of each round so you either score the tile or lose it. Then there is end of game scoring for set collection of different types of workers and jewelry that you buy over the course of the game using money collected each round. So do you stick with just scoring in the short term or sacrifice some of them to score in the long term. It's a thinky game but fun and looks extremely beautiful on the table even it does take up a lot of that table space.

item.name: Bruges
item.comment: This is a keeper. We're just getting into Eurogames really but this is one of the best. And from Feld no less. There honestly aren't too many of his games we'll enjoy. It's simple and direct. You get a few decisions to make with a hand of cards you've drawn. It is easy and flows very well. No point salad either. Plays in under an hour and is just fun.

item.name: Bruges: The City on the Zwin
Cacao
item.comment: In this tile laying game you are building up a jungle/cacao plantation in a style similar to Carcassonne. In it however you are gathering money and/or cacao beans or building up temples to score points. Each tile the players have allot different numbers of workers to each location they join with their tile. Thus you may have 2 workers on one side that gives you 2 cacao beans and also 1 worker that might give you money. The key in placing your tiles in such a way that it benefits you while giving your opponents nothing or perhaps blocking them out of something completely. This game has flown completely under the radar but is fun, good to look at, has a short play time (25-35 minutes we have found) and has some good strategy and tactics.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game
item.comment: Just too complicated for what should have been a simple 2-players card game. Each round you have to fight it out in several different ways to see who the winner is. Just bogs down so fast. And why oh why did FantasyFlight put this game into one of their standard size boxes? It could have just as easy been fitted into a standard expansion size box.

item.name: Carcassonne: South Seas
item.comment: This Carcassonne is a different bird from all the rest as you collect resources in order to load ships to receive points. For us it is just a bit fiddly with the placement of the meeples and the gathering of the resources. Especially the fish where you collect for everything in the water connected to where your meeple is then you place a small token to show that area is exhausted. It is fun but if we could only keep one it would be standard Carcassonne (or at least the Winter Edition we own).

item.name: Carcassonne: Winter Edition
item.comment: It's Carcassonne only more Winterry. We know. It's not a real word but that pretty much sums it up. One of the great gateways with better artwork on it. There is just something so simple about the tile placement. By the way we don't actually play with the meeples as farmers. I know. I know. We can hear the die hard gamers screaming, "Then you aren't playing it right!" But the one time we tried it just dragged the game out. So we play it to have fun and that's how we do it. And in the Winter Edition there's even a Wuzzle. Raise your hand if you get the obscure 80s cartoon/plush toy reference.

item.name: Carnival Zombie
item.comment: An evil, zombie-filled, Venice-based upgrade from Castle Panic that ups the challenge without pushing the complexity and difficulty into the stratosphere of impossibility. If you like Castle Panic but maybe think it's a bit too easy or you were catastrophically disappointed with Dead Panic you must give this one a try.

item.name: Castle Dice
item.comment: A fun, silly Euro with lots of dice to roll. No doubt the die hard Eurogamers want to vomit when they see all the cubes of disparate randomness but that is what makes this game fun. But that box! What the ....! I understand you want to list your Kickstarter backers but do that in the rulebook. Don't make a box that is 50% unusable space.

item.name: A Castle for All Seasons
item.comment: The art is beautiful but it is Michael Menzel so there's no surprise there. The game looks good on the table with lots of resource pieces and cardboard punch outs for each location you build. But for what seems to be a simple worker placement this one does get over wrought in its own mechanisms really quickly. You don't just build the building you take control of it in some way. It is difficult to explain. Granted the game play isn't difficult or fiddly to keep up with like in Caylus. But it just bogs down in a few mechanisms that seem to be made complex just to make them complex. And complexity for complexity's sake is something we hate in games.

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Castle Panic is how all co-ops should be. Add in the expansion and it's one of the best.

item.name: Castle Panic: The Dark Titan
item.comment: THis expansion makes Castle Panic even harder. And believe it or not that makes it even more fun. This is one of our favorite co-ops anyway and the Dark Titan makes it even better now with a massive boss that you are unlikely to defeat without all the proper planning.

item.name: Castle Panic: The Wizard's Tower
item.comment: Makes Castle panic even better. That's all we can say.

item.name: Castle: The Detective Card Game
item.comment: Huge fan of Castle but ... this is just an abstract card game with Castle photos (and theme) pasted on. Good way to spend time during the commercials maybe.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: Castles of Burgundy is Stefen Feld at his best. He once again takes the randomizing characteristics of 6-sided dice and turns them into something strategic. Each turn those dice rolls give you hard decisions to make. Take a building from the board, place said building or get workers to help you next turn. And while there is the chance you'll get shut out of what you really want you are never left without an option. It plays very easy. But the game can get a little long especially in the final rounds when your placement is so critical. If you are hesitant about buying your first Feld game we do not think you can go wrong starting with this one.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 5th Expansion – Pleasure Garden
item.comment: These tiles add some nice variety to the game.

item.name: Catan Geographies: Germany
item.comment: Thanks again to the Dice Tower's Sam Healey for bringing this one up. The board is beautiful (MIchael Menzel strikes again!) and it is so simple to play. It gives you the Catan feel but removes some of the complexity that kept us away from anything Catan for so long. Down side is that like all standard Catan games it is not set for two-players without having to use some wonky marketplace variant.

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment: Richard Ham must be stopped! Yup, his run through talked us into getting this one. Keep in mind it took us many , many months to get it. So ... sadly this one is not for us. Don't get us wrong. It is a very well-thought out game with cool components, interesting mechanics and not nearly as much of the FEED YOUR PEOPLE from Agricola. But it is just a bit too fiddly. There are so many components to keep up with, honestly too many choices to make and it just felt too long.And for those people who say that you can take many different paths to victory I say "Error!" I stuck with one path while my wife did everything. She CRUSHED me. So there goes that theory. Here's the weird thing. We did really have fun while we were playing it. But once we were done, had wrestled all that cardboard & wood back into the box, we looked at each other and both said , "Trade." There are people out there who will be able to play this behemoth each and every day and we applaud them. It is a fun game. We liken it to those movies that you enjoy but after you watch it the first time there is no reason to see it again.

item.name: Champions of Midgard
item.comment: This game might just make sure Lords of Waterdeep stays on the shelf or perhaps even traded away. A really thematic working placement game about being a Viking warlord leading your men to victory over trolls, the undead and monsters across the sea. The look of the game in gorgeous and its gameplay is quick and simply but still requires you to put some thought into each placement. You collect your warriors (otherwise known as dice) to take on creatures tormenting towns and villages. And while it does use dice for combat they do not make the game as random as dice in other games. many of the monsters, etc you fight are not terribly tough so they can be defeated with only 1-5 hits. But ti is managing the use of those dice so you don't lose them all in every battle that sets up the strategy. In addition you have to manage a small number of resources in order to better your odds of defeating your foes. It's fun, not too long and lends a fair amount of them through the art and game play. The only real downside to this game is that we discovered it after backing Raiders of the North Sea on Kickstarter. Alas Champions of Midgard has a similar theme but is a better game so Raiders will be going on the trade pile still in shrink.

item.name: Chupacabra: Survive the Night
item.comment: Rolling dice. Ok rolling glow in the dark dice. But there's no game with this one. Just glow in the dark dice.

item.name: Circus Train (Second edition)
item.comment: A fun theme. But lack luster components (it is Victory Point games so it shouldn't come as a surprise) and way too complicated and fiddly game play make this one a no go for us.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: CITADELS! (raise your hand if you're an Eric Summerer fan) Small box but a pretty fair amount of game in it. It's taken us a while to actually give this one a try but it's good so far. Only have played it a few times ( and those with 3 players) I don't know if it will work well just doing 2 players. Given the role selection mechanism just not sure if it can scale down well.

item.name: Coal Baron
item.comment: This reminds us quite a bit of another Kramer and Kiesling game we love; Tikal. Similar but not the same. You assign workers (not really workers in a sense but more like the time each worker uses in the day) to spots to gather coal, distribute that coal, fulfill contracts or just get income. The intriguing part is how you'll use those "workers." The 1st person in a spot gets it for 1 worker. The next players can use that space but they must use 1 more worker than the previously player who placed there. If it was 1 you must use 2. If it was 2 you must use 3 and so on. It makes you think ahead for your moves in a very strategic manner. Plus after each shift you score for certain elements of the game. But you must keep those elements in mind for the future because at the end of each shift you score not just for the current elements but for past elements as well. So you have to plan well and use your workers wisely.

item.name: Compounded
item.comment: hated chemistry as a kid. I honestly don't know what i was thinking getting this game. It seemed like it might be a fun Euro despite the theme. It's main downfall is a two-player variant that uses a dummy player that just doesn't work.

item.name: Concordia
item.comment: Thank you! No roundel. Love this game. One of our favorite Euros. And despite what the rules say you can easily play 2-player on the Empire side of the board without it bogging down the game or making it too easy for anyone. It's a must have in our opinion. There is one thing about this game that baffles me. And it is in other Euros as well. If scoring only occurs at the end of the game, why is there a scoring track on the board?

item.name: Conquest of Planet Earth: The Space Alien Game
Courtier
item.comment: Love the artwork. The simplicity of game play is awesome. And just cut-throat enough for us to like it. But in a 2-player game it becomes wildly unbalanced because of those coterie cards. And this game began to make us understand that area control games just don't typically support 2 players.

item.name: Cruel Necessity
item.comment: Picked this one up after watching it on Box of Delights. I love the historic nature of the game. You get to learn about the British Civil War as you play the game. But you are just constantly rolling dice. And if you roll badly (like I tend to do) you are not going to do well. There is very little you can do to mitigate the dice so the game just sort of beats you down round after round if you roll poorly (did I mention dice tend to hate me?). But it is an educational game and the graphic design is some of Victory Point Games's best.

item.name: Cthulhu Fluxx
item.comment: Just like everything else Cthulhu-related there is the chance that no one wins. The best Fluxx you can buy.

item.name: Cthulhu Gloom
item.comment: see Gloom

item.name: Dark Gothic
item.comment: Ok. So maybe this one is our favorite deck builder. IT plays essentially like Ascension but with theme and without the terrible artwork. say what you want about the costumed characters in photo on the cards but that is really awesome, we don't care what you say! We have been having tons of fun with this game and will continue to do so in the future. As well as looking forward to all the expansions.

item.name: Dark Gothic: Colonial Horror
item.comment: This adds even more to an already good game. Nothing terribly spectacular just more cards , more heroes and more villains to the base game. And finally a box to store all the cards in properly as well. A must buy if you like Dark Gothic.

item.name: Dark Tales
item.comment: Dark Tales is card game that at first seems rather simple. BUt there is a fair bit of tactics and strategy involved weith how you play the cards and also to where they have to be played. cards played in front of you give bonuses while cards played into a center display offer instant effects as well as the chance to gain benefits in the future. Cards collect into sets that might have future advantages to either or both players as well. each game you play has a card drawn that gives you a way to score points during the game. As well as a card for end game scoring. With these you have some variability from game to game. The art is fantastic and some of the best I've seen for such a small game. If you're looking for theme though you won't find it here. But what you will find is a game that is fun to play and gorgeous to look at.

item.name: Dark Tales: Little Red Riding Hood
item.comment: This expansion doesn't bring as much to the game as the Snow White expansion. But it is still good with new cards and their effect. And more scoring options. My hope with seeing this is that Hobby World will continue making more and more expansions. I look forward, hopefully, to seeing a Beauty & The Beast expansion or a Sleeping Beauty expansion.

item.name: Dark Tales: Snow White
item.comment: Snow White adds more cards, more tokens and scoring cars. It doesn't change game play at all but gives you more of what you like if you like this game. Plus there is some theme there with the way the tokens interact with certain characters. And you can tell the people who designed this game are fans of not just fairy tales but the original fairy tales since they put in the burning shoes that allow you to score by discarding an Evil Queen. You have to understand the original Grimm fairy tales to get the meaning of some of the content.

item.name: Darkest Night: Necromancer Bundle
item.comment: This is another of those games we hear described as "Arkham Horror Lite." And it is close with the mechanics, dice rolling and theme. But we think the difficulty and rules set is right up there with AH. The only places it falls into "Light" are the footprint and the components. The board is small and there are only a few decks of cards to draw from. So if you are looking for a game with Arkham Horror's level of theme and difficulty but don't want a game that devours two tables if you use more than one expansion this might be the one you're looking for.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment: This one is a conundrum. For gaming it is typically only my wife and I. So having any game with a traitor element in it is a bit dodgy. We picked this up after seeing all the hype and after playing a three player game with a friend. We had watched a play through online with someone playing it as purely co-op. However that seems to bring out the worst in the game really. Obviously the traitor elements of the game have to be removed. Then you have to play the game on the hard difficulty in order to make the co-op mode challenging. Problem is that mode might just be too hard. But if you tone it back and don't play on the hard mode it becomes too easy. It's hard to tell what will be with Dead of Winter for now. Regardless of whether it not it stays in our collection we are still keeping the "Lucky Luke" and"Felicia Day" promos.

item.name: Deadwood
item.comment: With most worker placement games you are trying to collect resources in order to accomplish one goal or another that in the end will score you points in order to win the game. Deadwood removes the goal aspect of a worker placement game. In this game you are simply placing workers in order to get money which is points at the end of the game. In short it removes a major aspect of what a worker placement game is. And it doing so it makes the game dull and monotonous.

item.name: Defenders of the Realm
item.comment: It's Pandemic with orcs and dragons. Oh and dice rolling. All these things combine to make it a fun game but it just cannot live up to the game it so obviously owes itself to. Plus despite it saying it is a 1-4 player game we dare you to try it 1 or 2 player. It destroyed us mercilessly every time. We now play with 2 characters each making it basically a 4 player only game. Not tried it with 3, might work. That said we are still holding onto our copy.

item.name: Desperados of Dice Town
item.comment: This game has a good concept. You roll the dice matching symbols to try and break out your outlaw gang before the other player. But there are a couple things working against it. First of all is the dice. You get 4. Each has the symbol of different members of your gang on it to match up. They are cool etched dice but only having 4 of them hampers certain mechanisms in the game. There are certain matching dice rolls of 2-4 symbols that enable you to use either special abilities on outlaws already free or to get a card that gives you a benefit. The problem with these is that with only 4 dice the rolling of them to try and free your outlaws is so tight that should you decide to try and do either of these things you are going to fall behind the other players. This isn't so much an issue with the outlaws special powers which some only require one matching symbol on the dice but the cards require at least 3. Now if they had put 6 dice in the game it would not make the game so tight and it might make trying to get those cards worth it. But with only 4 ... well, the few times we played we never even tried to get a card for fear of falling behind and losing. These things combined together made Desperadoes a game wherein you MUST play it a certain way or you'll lose. Now maybe that gets mitigated with more than 2 players but it makes it not a good game for us.

item.name: Dice Brewing
item.comment: This little game is a bit more interesting than it at first seems. We did manage to get a KS edition in trade so it has some nice extras like play mats for each player. It's essentially dice placement where over time you can upgrade the dice for higher values. The dice represent beers you are making for sale to the public that will get you points, cash and benefits. You also collect resources to enhance your beers and make them worth more of the aforementioned. The game is nothing innovative or groundbreaking but it is fun and good to look at with steam punk art. Why steam punk in a light Euro about beer making I have no idea. That said, it does have some problems. The resources you get to enhance your brews are tiny circular chits that sit on cards to store them. The cards are not nearly big enough. So every time you pick up one of those resources you are going to knock over the rest. Why they didn't just make a market board or something like that I don't get since they had player mats. Plus the iconography is not intuitive. We are constantly having to look back at the rule book to know what they mean. Good game but it sure could use some polish.

item.name: Dice Town
item.comment: In Dice Town you roll dice trying to get the best kind of poker hands on the dice for the best benefit. It really is as simple as that. Plays in less than 30 minutes (at least we know that for a fact with 2 players) but still gives you some strategic choices to make along the way. This is very easily a gateway game that you can teach to someone who knows cards but has never touched a designer board game in their life.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Dominion is an awesome game the began a genre. Vaccarino would seem to be a genius for coming up with deck-building. Though we do feel sorry for him. He created this epic game that has defined an entire genre of game that will not go away. Thus he will be forever judged by that epic creation. And he will never be able to match it much less surpass it. That said we just cannot see keeping it. We have so many other deck builders that are better and with theme , something Dominion is sadly lacking in. So while it is an incredible game it isn't for us.

item.name: The Doom That Came To Atlantic City
item.comment: Cthulhu-opoly? Yeah. Pretty much. There's really nothing special here just a whimsical take on Monopoly that includes the Cthulhu Mythos theme. Our main problem with this is the art throughout the game. The art on the player board and especially the miniatures is AWESOME! Terrific graphic design. But then you get to the other cards and they are designed like some strange twisted My Little Pony art. I will never understand why some companies do this. Just keep your artwork and graphic design consistent.

item.name: Double Shutter
item.comment: Just a fun dice chucking game where you try to match the numbers you roll to the flip tiles and get them all turned down. A solo waste of time but an entertaining one.

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: My wife said it best : The Carcassonne of Death! LOL. But this is a seriously good game. In the first half you are placing members of your patrician family into locations through out the city. Every now and then this delightful card called an "omen" gets drawn that allows you to throw an opponent's family member into the volcano. Yes, there is a plastic piece that gets inserted into the board to represent Vesuvius. At a certain point in the game an "AD 79" card will be drawn that halts the first half of the game. From this point on your are attempting to get your people out of the city while drawing lava tiles to place throughout the city (a bit incorrect in the theme since Pompeii was buried in ash by pyroclastic flows but lava tile sounds better than pyroclastic flow tile I suppose) to possibly block exits from the city or to just kill other opponents' family members. A very morbid and macabre theme if you think about it too much but the game abstracts it nicely. The person who has the most family member saved when the lava tiles run out wins the game. For some extra added fun look up the "Doctor Who" variant on BGG. If you are a fan of the show you will love this fan-inspired variant.

item.name: Draco Magi
item.comment: Maybe we are doing something wrong here. We got this game because Launius's name was on it. he is one of our favorite designers so we just had to try it. But after a single round of play, round mind you not game, we were bored. In one round you play cards at locations, next round you do ranged attack by drawing cards from a deck (War style) to see who wins and who loses. Then you go through a round of melee combat. You fight at 3 different locations possibly using 8-16 dragons and about 10-14 cards per player. But it just felt like "I play this card. Oh you countered it. Ok Your turn. You play that card. Oh I countered it." before we had even scored one location we were out of cards. And when that happens subsequent combat is resolved by drawing cards off the deck and comparing them just like War. Like we said perhaps we are just playing this all wrong.

item.name: Dragon Strike
item.comment: I mainly remember this game for the instruction VHS that game with it that actually starred one of the guys from American Gladiator. But it was also fun to play with pretty good components for that time. Though it was clearly just TSR trying to cash in on MB's success with Heroquest.

item.name: Dragon's Hoard
item.comment: This card game is one of the best small box games you can buy. Plus if you know someone who likes Uno I think you'll easily be able to talk them into this game. The art is stellar and the game play is just so so easy. You can teach this one in a matter of minutes but we think you'll be enjoying it for years.

item.name: Dune Express
item.comment: We have been wanting to try Dune ever since we discovered the board gaming hobby. But either the game is too expensive, too hard to find, in bad shape when it isn't expensive or a bit too pricey for modern versions. Then there is the concept of will this game play any good with just 2 players since alliances usually play a big part of the board game. But with Express we have found a way to play it that isn't pricey, hard to find or just as satisfying with 2 players. All the cards are replaced with dice. Yes, it just makes it random but we still get the experience of mining Arrakis and trying to dominate the planet for our House. So maybe rolling dice and playing out actions isn't as thematic as the alliances, control and traitors that are in the board game, the flavor is still there and it is a fun game that won't wear out its welcome.

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: Silly dice-chucking fun. It's really a bit of an abstract game but it lets you play a sort of dungeon crawl in about 20-30 minutes. Two players is best because then the other person gets to laugh maniacally as they roll 4 dragons for you to fight. Plus this game comes with the best quality dice we have found in any game thus far.

item.name: Dungeon Roll: Hero Booster Pack #1
item.comment: A nice little addition to a nice little game.

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment: Be as negative as you want. Yes, there is a !@#$%^&-ton of luck in this game. We actually beat Hastur recently without ever getting a Doom token on his card. Yes, it does all come down to dice-rolling. But the game never professes to be anything but that. A dice-rolling game. And for our money it is the best dice-rolling game out there and themed quite nicely.

item.name: Elder Sign: Gates of Arkham
item.comment: This takes Elder Sign from a fantastic game to one of our top 10 games. Don't get us wrong we love exploring the museum in Arkham to discover what secrets lie buried there. But going out into Arkham in Gates of Arkham has us wondering if we will ever explore the museum again. Location cards now come out face down when new cards come out. On the back they have abilities that benefit you but usually at the cost of trophies or time. neither if which you really want to use. But if turning the clock forward three times gets you an ally how useful will that be? It makes exploring the town a big part of the game. Then there are gates that open into other worlds. And just like in Arkham Horror you have to get these things closed. Ignore them and you WILL pay the price. On top of all that you have event cards that might trigger when you explore a location. Some are good. Most are bad. Beware! We played this expansion at Dice Tower Con where Richard Launius was demoing it. We honestly had no interest in getting this at first figuring ti was gonna ruin the game. But we had so much fun playing games with Richard at the previous DTC that we tried it anyway. And are we happy we did! he told us expansions would be forthcoming. Now if it is just more locations in Arkahm that will be great. But what would be awesome would be Elder Sign : Gates of Innsmouth or Gates of Dunwich. Here's to hoping.

item.name: Elder Sign: Unseen Forces
item.comment: Adds some complexity and more versatility to the base game. It's a must have if you like Elder Sign. But we advise against some of the modules in it. Some of the Great Old Ones are just a bit (actually a lot) too hard.

item.name: Eldritch Horror
item.comment: It's a globe spanning adventure with horrific mysteries to solve and sanity-shattering forces to combat. But ... It just cannot hold a candle to Arkham Horror for us. Despite it being wider in scope it doesn't feel as immersive. The concept of solving mysteries to accomplish your goals instead of closing gates is novel but in order to make that goal viable the game must have a timer. And the mythos deck serves that purpose. But we just do not like that timer aspect. Plus if the mystery cards get drawn in a certain order you can be stalled out quite quickly. During one game fighting Cthulhu, the epic monster corresponding to a certain mystery card came out and we were never able to defeat it. So while Eldritch Horror draws you into a more expansive world the gameplay, unfortunately, contracts the experience in such a way that it feels smaller somehow.

item.name: Eldritch Horror: Forsaken Lore
item.comment: This is a decent expansion. It's basically another Old One (Yig) to fight and more cards for the base game. Nothing special really. If you never get it for the base game we don't think you'll be missing anything.

item.name: Eminent Domain
item.comment: This one put Race for the Galaxy on the trade list. It is such a simple deck builder but with enough strategy to keep it from being too easy. Components are awesome but what can you expect from Tasty Minstrel Games. We do wish the technology cards were handled a bit differently. We hate having to keep referring back to the rule to see what we can get as ALL the tech is available from round 1. We think it might work better by categorizing the tech cards into levels that come out for purchases as the game progresses. But other than that this game plays perfect and without Race for the Galaxy's lexicon of iconography.

item.name: Eminent Domain: Escalation
item.comment: Now the ship designs have meaning. The scenario cards that determine how each player starts the game is so much better than the standard set up that I cannot really say how much we love it. And some of the new technologies are awesome. That being said we must once again come back the technologies cards and their all inclusive availability. At least with the standard game you could just look at the back of the rule book and try to decide what tech you wanted. But Escalation adds SSSOOOO many more technologies that now you are reading through several pages of the rule book each turn trying to decide what you will buy with your research. It inevitably stops the game dead for minutes while one of use looks through both rulebooks to see what we want. There has to be a better way. Should a game come out with similar game play but no all inclusive tech this and the base game may go on the trade list. Maybe I need to look through the forums and see if anyone has come up with anything.

item.name: Entdecker: Exploring New Horizons
item.comment: We would say this is the love child of Carcassone and Tsuro of the Seas but this originally came out before both. It might be the best tile exploration game out there. You explore the undiscovered seas looking for land to score. You can go cheap and hope for the best flipping tiles that might or might not help you build your route. Or you spend more to start with tiles that you can see how they can be laid out. Along the way you make friends with the natives and try to earn their favor. It plays very easily but it plays a bit long for us. That might be because we are just playing 2 players though we can see some AP and down time issues coming in with 3-4. Regardless it is an awesome game and certainly a keeper.

item.name: Euphoria: Build a Better Dystopia
item.comment: This worker placement game deserves to be much higher than 242 on the BGG list. At least top 100. It is innovative and easy to play. Yes, you look at that board and think "Wow! That looks busy!" But it isn't. The game play is relatively simple but with enough strategy that you cannot just blunder through it and hope to win. The worker placement is different in that you can bump other people's workers and take that spot, though in doing so you give them back a worker to place on their turn. Euphoria is filled with other neat mechanisms like the morale & intelligence tracks and being able to gain allegiances with factions on the board . This is a great game and everyone ought to check it out so it can be higher as it deserves.

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: This one get a 5 simply because of the art. It is fantastic. But the game ... SIGH. Despite what it says on the box it does not support two players in our opinion. Drafting games by definition really need at least 3 people. Otherwise they are what Fairy Tale is if you try with just 2 players, BORING. And it doesn't even have any kind of 2-player variant like 7 Wonders or Among the Stars. Nope. You just play it the same with 2 as with 5. Which, did we mention makes it BORING.

item.name: Fantastiqa
item.comment: A deck building game with some classical artwork on many of the cards and components. It gives the whole game a style that lets you feel like you're playing inside some childishly strange fantasy world. Which is the point after all. Using the cards you have you move through this world gathering more resources in order to score points to win the game. This game reminds us in some ways of a much much MUCH lighter version of Mage Knight. In fact after playing this game we traded Mage Knight for that reason. Fantasiqa gives you the feel of exploring a fantasy realm but without the novella of rules you need to understand in order to play Mage Knight.

item.name: Le Fantôme de l'Opéra
item.comment: Not fans of deduction games but we got this after watching ... you guessed it... Richard Ham doing a Rahdo Run Through. We enjoyed our first play but after that we have had no desire to get it out onto the table. Guess we still just aren't deduction fans. Odd since I am a huge Sherlock Holmes fan.

item.name: Firefly: Out to the Black
item.comment: We never though a small card game could get this fiddly. 3-5 players? First time we've ever seen a co-op (without a traitor) that needs a minimum of three. Of course the rules say a player can use more than one character but then explains that if you use 2 characters you can only use the special ability of 1 of those players per game. We can see what Toy Vault was trying to do. They were trying to take the "job" action of the Firefly Board Game and turn it into a game unto itself. Unfortunately it doesn't work. And aside from the pictures it doesn't represent the Firefly theme at all. This one's an epic fail.

item.name: Firefly: The Game
item.comment: At it's heart this is a pick up and deliver game. But it's a pick up and deliver game set in Joss Whedon's Firefly universe. And with each play you will feel like you're cruising through the 'Verse trying to make a living as well as stay alive and free. The only reason this one doesn't get a 10 is because of the length. Despite the box and adventure cards telling you it will play in 2 hours that will not happen. Set aside 3+ hours for this game.

item.name: Firefly: The Game – Breakin' Atmo
item.comment: Adds a bit more but not much really. Just a few more items and crew for purchase. But makes this game we love just a bit better.

item.name: Fluxx Promo Cards
item.comment: We have the Hastur promo for Cthulhu Fluxx. A nice addition. Wish they'd make more for it.

item.name: Forbidden Desert
item.comment: We have to disagree with what most people seem to be saying about this one. All we read or hear is how much better this is than Forbidden Island. But we think it's too complicated for what it is. Whereas "Island" was a step-child of Pandemic with much easier mechanics, "Desert" reaches Pandemic's complexity but in just a bit less play time.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: The best small game that money can buy if you ask us. With this you get the sense of something Pandemic-ish (nope. not a real word) without the time or complexity. Awesome components and a terrific design. Just as good as Pandemic.

item.name: Forge War
item.comment: This is the poster child for the cold soulless Euro. Yes there is good art. But nothing really lends to the theme. For starters to gather the resources you need to move forward you basically play a game of YINSH to get them. And you do this every round to gather the resources. Then you do worker placement to build what you need to accomplish quests. And by the way those worker placement choices are always obvious. And should you get shut out of what you really need you'll fall behind. Then to score points you must advance on quest cards that you buy. I'm sorry .. buying a quest? I get that you are playing the "manager" of the people going on the quest ( a concept that still sounds a bit off let's be honest) but buying a quest? But back to advancing on the quests. Do you fight the menacing creatures depicted on the quest cards? Nope. You just have to have the resources to advance when that step of the game comes around. Then you do it all over again. And again. And again. AND AGAIN! This game is so boring. It took forever and that was on the short game. The art is good and the concept is ok ( I won't say unique because the concept of being the mastermind behind the shadows is already out there in Lords of Waterdeep) but the designer just made this game so complex and overwrought for no good reason. Maybe if the quests were done is a less boring way and you didn't start every round playing YINSH Forge War could have been something special. But as it stands it's nothing but rather, rinse, repeat only far more repetitive.

item.name: Fortune and Glory: Danger Pack 1 Supplement
item.comment: see Fortune and Glory : The Cliffhanger Game

item.name: Fortune and Glory: Rise of the Crimson Hand
item.comment: see Fortune and Glory : The Cliffhanger Game

item.name: Fortune and Glory: Sands of Cairo
item.comment: see Fortune and Glory : The Cliffhanger Game

item.name: Fortune and Glory: The Cliffhanger Game
item.comment: First let's deal with the elephant in the room. WHAT IS WITH THAT BOX?! What was Flying Frog thinking? This game could easily have gone into the same size box as A Touch of Evil. Ok. That out of the way ... this game is awesome! It is one of the most thematic games you will find on the market. And yes, it does have a lot of rules and a lot of dice-rolling. But that is what Ameri-thrash (Thank you Zee Garcia for getting that trend started) games are all about. Plus with Flying Frog you get some of the best components money can buy. And on top of all that you get to play at being Indiana Jones! And who doesn't want to do that. It is nice to see that FFP has gotten their rules a bit better flushed out with this game than they did with A Touch of Evil. Speaking of which, this game and Dark Gothic have gotten us to give ToE another look and we have fallen in love with that game again. But we're talking about this game, right? The rounds play quickly once you have a few games under your belt and you understand the rules. You have this vast world on the game board to explore. It can be one sided in the competitive game if by luck of the draw three treasures appear with 2 spaces of your opponent's starting location. But the co-op rules are awesome and unlike ToE they don't seem to have been an after thought add in. Have not tried the team play yet but we can see that as being a bit too much to keep up with. What else can we say? Fortune and Glory, kid. Fortune and Glory.

item.name: Fortune and Glory: Treasure Hunters Expansion
item.comment: see Fortune and Glory : The Cliffhanger Game

item.name: Freedom: The Underground Railroad
item.comment: Freedom is a well designed game with easy game play and a heavy theme. This is the soul of what a good co-op ought to be. Challenging and thinky. Each round you get to do one action on the board but you feel like you need to be doing 5 at least. The problem for us was that the theme was too heavy, too immersive. And that is not a fault in the game. The historical accuracy and immersion this brings out is intense. However, when playing Pandemic it is abstracted to the point where when that outbreak happens in Jakarta I don't feel anything emotionally. In Freedom because the theme of slavery and abolition is so well represented that every time a slave catcher moves or a slave gets put back into the market we feel horrible. The slaves are abstracted by unpainted wooden cubes but that doesn't seem to help. So while this is an awesome co-op that deserves all the accolades it has gotten, the theme is ironically too well represented.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: I wonder what got us interested in trying this one? If you guessed Richard Ham you are correct! Curse that man and his love of Eurogaming. Were it not for him we wouldn't have half the games we do. LOL. But he's backed a winner with Fresco. There is a lot of set up to it but at least you have something very pretty to look at once you're done. At its heart Fresco is worker placement and resource management at its simplest. We love the way it all coalesces into painting that beautiful fresco to score the points you need. There are just 2 things keeping this from a 10. 1) All the expansions. You really don't need them. They truly just add complexity for complexity's sake. Mind you we are saying this from a non-die-hard Eurogamer POV. So take that for what you will. 2) The Leonardo dummy player that is used in the 2-player game. We have no problem with dummy players in some games (Mage KNight and Pergamon) when they move independently. But a dummy player whose actions are controlled by the players is not a dummy player. No matter what you call it the dummy is a part of your strategy and it can be a part of that strategy you plan for. Luckily we have devised a way for Leonardo to move on his own. Yes. It is random and involves dice so we can hear the die-hard Euros screaming once more but we prefer it to the designer's way because it actually makes him a "dummy" player not a part of the players' strategy.

item.name: Fresco: Expansion Modules 4, 5 and 6
item.comment: The components are good. But as previously mentioned we just think the expansions for Fresco bog the game down.

item.name: Friday
item.comment: A deck builder for one? Yes, Friday fills that niche (was there a niche for a solitaire deck builder?) quite well. Fun but challenging. You start so weak you can barely do anything but then you start building yourself up little by little. Nothing is easy however and at no point does this feel like something you can breeze through. Alas as a solitaire game it won't hit the table much but it's a good way to pass 30 + minutes if you're itching for a game and no one to game with.

item.name: Gear & Piston
item.comment: And Richard Ham does it again folks. I think if we ever stop watching Rahdo Runs Through ... we will end up with less games. But this one isn't going anywhere. We love the idea of building things in a game but most of them are sooooooo complex it gives me an AP headache just watching it being played (Shipyard!). But Gear & Piston plays easily and without too many decisions to be made along the way. Playing those tiles out before me and seeing my car come together is just fun.

item.name: Geister, Geister, Schatzsuchmeister!
item.comment: A simple game with great components. But for such a simple game is it too freaking hard! I mean like we never won a single game or even came close on the basic game.

item.name: Gem Rush
item.comment: This one is a bit of a conundrum. Simple, short and fun. But the components just aren't quite up to par, even by Victory Point standards. The cards were warped as soon as the box opened and the little dwarf miner standees do not hold together for play. In addition to that there are certain combinations of room cards that would allow a player just to move back and forth between two rooms getting points enabling them to win without having to explore any further. That breaks a game in my opinion but at least it does not come up often.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment: We are all about challenge in a co-op game. But a co-op game that beats you in less than 30 minutes on the easiest setting? Nope. One play was all it took for this and it was into the library of our friendly local game store.

item.name: Glass Road
item.comment: Glass Road was fun the first time we played it at a demo during DTC 2014. We bought it not long after but found it lacking in one major aspect. We played it with a 5 player compliment but we usually only play bu ourselves (two-player) and it just doesn't work that well for 2. And it relies a lot on the interaction with the players for the playing of character cards to perform actions. And as stated we typically just have only the 2 of us so that interaction kind of falls away making the game a bit of a slog to play through. Otherwise it is a fine game. The massive number of components that Uwe normally stuffs his game boxes with is replaced by a resource wheel. You manipulate that wheel to get more of one resource which will in turn use up another as you move the dial. It is a really good system for resource management. So as stated a very good game with interesting mechanisms but best played with more than 2 players.

item.name: Gloom
item.comment: A fun little story telling card game. The downside is you have to play with people who are good at telling stories. If they aren't then you're just playing a push your luck game with see through (we do love this part of the game though and wish there were other games using it) cards.

item.name: Granada
item.comment: It's Alhambra but with added mechanisms and complexity. That makes it not nearly as good when it is essentially the same game. It is really fiddly with having to flip tiles as they come out depending on what the game dictates that round. I think maybe we just love the simplicity of Alhambra so much that this game sort of wears on us. But still going to hold onto it if for no other reason that we love using its beautiful board to play Alhambra on.

item.name: Guildhall
item.comment: This one is fun all around. Though it is fairly abstract the art is awesome and the game play is so smooth. If there is one drawback it's that in a 2-player game is definitely loses some of its meaner "take that" moments. Which you might view as a good or bad thing depending on how much you like "take that" games. It works well either way for us. However.... this box! AEG! What were you thinking? As soon as the cards come our of the wrap there's no way to store the game unless you have deck boxes or bags. Why no insert?

item.name: Guildhall: Job Faire
item.comment: More Guilds for Guildhall? We'll take it. Plus this has a way to store all the Guildhall cards! Thank you AEG!

item.name: The Hanging Gardens
item.comment: This one was hard to get a hold of but well worth it. Essentially a tile laying / set collection game, the Hanging Gardens plays as easily as any other of that type and looks good on the table doing it. each round you will select cards to place in your tableau to try and make matches of certain types of terrain. But the cards must be laid out in such ways that spaces only overlap if there is a spot on an underlying card. So you have to place the cards very strategically especially since you want the same terrains to be side by side in certain numbers so that you can place temples on them in order to collect point tiles. The more tiles of one type of terrain you can collect the more points you will receive at the end of the game.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment: maybe it is unfair to rank Hansa at 6. It is a good game with ease of play and some strategy. perhaps if we had found this early in our gaming "career" we might have enjoyed it. But it is so simple that we found it to be boring. It's a "trading in the Mediterranean" game but it is that genre at its most basic. So compared with games like Concordia it just cannot hold our interest. Plus the components are a joke really. The "player board" is just a 5 inch card board cut out with a 1 inch diameter icon in the middle that represents where you put your coins. That was a waste of cardboard in all honesty. I don't need a player board just to stack my money on. So it is a basic Euro and if you are just getting started with gaming in that fashion this might be a good pick.

item.name: Harbour
item.comment: OH MY GOD! This may be the most boring game we have ever played. It's been hyped as a light version of Le Havre. In that aspect there description is correct. But while Le havre is an engaging game with lots of decisions, Harbour is neither engaging or nor filled with decisions. Like Le havre you get one "worker" to place each round in order to get goods to sell for profit and points. There is a revolving market that over the course of the game makes some goods worth more and some worth less. the market movement is not secret so you can plan for it. However, for the first 3rd of the game the only thing you will be doing is placing your worker on your only player board each turn just to try and build up goods so that you can sell to that market. Plus what you have to do is so obvious each turn given what the market wants that it makes the game play dull. The only really strategic thing you are doing is trying to build up to sell or buy from the market. And that is basically the game. You look at the market, establish what you obviously need to do and do that.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: Yes. There are a lot of components. A LOT! And yes the set up time can be up there with Arkham Horror. But this is a good game. With each round you feel as though you are building up your own industry (sometimes standing on your friend's shoulders to do it). It also plays quick and there is always something you can do. Did you opponent take the franks you wanted to build that Smokehouse? Fine. Just use his slaughterhouse to make some meat and sell that next turn. You're never blocked out in this game. And if you decide not to pursue some aspect of the industry you aren't penalized for it. By the time you are finished with this game you really feel like you've built something. Unfortunately this game just doesn't have the re playability we'd hoped. After a few plays it has become the same every time.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: We aren't big on abstract games but this is one we can get behind. It's fun, easy and strategic.

item.name: Hive: The Pillbug
item.comment: see Hive

item.name: Hunter's Guild: The Vampire Forest
item.comment: This one is simple but fun. True gamers need not apply. Draw a card from the Night deck and fight it with what is in your hand. Draw from the Day deck to increase your hand. If you draw the Vampire Lord and have the right cards in hand, you win. No strategy. No tactics. Just simple luck and fun. Think Talisman crushed down into a card game.

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: Just as solid a game as 51st State. Designed by the same man it both expands and simplifies that game. Which can be a total Catch 22 because maybe what you like is the complexity. Or maybe you like the game play but complexity of it bogs you down. It's a toss up really but a simple decision if you like 51st State but find yourself bogging down in its game play pick this game up instead.

item.name: Impulse
item.comment: Bad components. I cannot say the art was bad because there is no art honestly. Don't believe me? Look up the images for this game. The game play is so clunky you can practically hear it banging along as you play. It is amazing that a card game can be made into something this over wrought.

item.name: In Magnificent Style
item.comment: I have my doubts sometimes about Victory Point Games. But not with this one. "In Magnificent Style" is VPG at their best. If you only own one solo game make it this one.

item.name: Infinite City
item.comment: Cutthroat Corporate Carcassonne. In a way yes. Infinite City is simply a game of placing tiles in front of you. But those tiles may have special abilities that allow you to manipulate the tiles themselves, your player pawns that you place out on the tiles or other players' pawns. You want to be the first to get all your pawns out because that triggers the end of the game but you also need to be in the lead for pints through out the scoring in the tiles. So it is like Carcassonne in the tile laying but unlike that family friendly game you are constantly doing things to trip up your opponents.

item.name: La Isla
item.comment: Stefan Feld makes another great game that is apparently being over looked because it isn't terribly heavy. I mean come on! This game is #597 on the Geek List. It is fantastic. In La Isla instead of using dice to determine any actions you get a hand of cards. Each turn you get to do three different things with those cards. You can use them to get special abilities that make it easier for you accomplish your goals. But don;t get used to those abilities as you can only have a certain number of them and every turn you add a new ability so you are gonna lose one of them sooner or later. You can use the card to get the resources you need to explore the island and observe unique animals. or you can use the cards to make certain animal inherently more valuable point wise by the end of the game. there are strategic and tactical decisions to make each and every turn. This game needs to be played by more people.

item.name: Island Siege
item.comment: Picked this little gem up on a whim at the friendly local game shop. Looked like it could be fun and was less that $20 bucks. But there is definitely more than $20 worth of game in that little box. A tight , short resource management game with combat. I can hear the Eurogamers now. "Combat in a resource management game! How dare you?!" I jest of course. We are coming to enjoy Euros now but that's beside the point. The component quality is ... random I guess is the best word. The cards are medium stock and ought to be sleeved. But there are these awesome metal coins in the box as well as tiny little meeples. Grab it up if you see a copy. It will surprises you.

item.name: Isle of Skye: From Chieftain to King
item.comment: Carcassonne: The Auction. Silly I know but if you've played this game you might just agree with that assessment. Each round you get a hand of tiles. You must discard one and bid money for the rest. Then you reveal and try to get those tiles that you've put money towards. problem is players can always hold money back and buy those tiles out from under you. So you have to think about what tiles you want and try to reason out what tiles your opponents may want. Plan right and you can keep your tile, get one from an opponent and even make money for future rounds. The tile placement is same as you need to get certain tiles at certain because each round there is a scoring phase. And in future rounds you will score the same thing again and again. So it is critical to get what you need to score while either making your opponents pay through the nose for what they need or juts outright deny them that tile by discarding it. So it is a bit like Carcassonne but with an auctioning mechanism that we really enjoy (an exception to rule since we normally hate auction games).

item.name: Istanbul
item.comment: This one clearly ranks as one of our favorite Euros. A worker placement game with simple rules and just enough strategy to keep you thinking from the first move to the last. You move about Istanbul (was Constantinople!) collecting wares and selling them or using them to buy the rubies you need to win the game. Along the way you gamble, have your near do well family go out & do some business for you and even visit a beautiful fountain. The production is top notch and the theme is fairly strong if off-putting to some. We love it a lot. We are really hoping an expansion or two might come out because that will make this already great game a perfect 10 possibly.
