item.name: Jamaica
item.comment: We don't play racing games too often. But the Dice Tower guys talk about this game soooooooo much that we just had to give it a try. And we were not disappointed. Jamaica is a solid game with some of the simplest mechanics put into a game together with some of the best components. You race around the island of Jamaica collecting gold, food and powder in order to outrace and out fight your opponents. Dead simple but so much fun it's almost criminal. Even the two player variant with the Ghost Ship is easy to play unlike most two player variants that involve dummy players. If only that hadn't made the rule book like a treasure map! It makes it such a pain to look up any rules. Fortunately they're aren't a lot of them. Check it out! It won't disappoint!

item.name: Jambo
item.comment: Somebody talks enough about a game and chances are we going to give it a go. It's thanks to the Dice Tower's Zee Garcia that we gave this a try. And it is very very good. It's a simple, easy flowing game with a fair amount of strategy that you must employ or you will lose. The art is fantastic on all the cards and it even travels easy. Toss all the components in a zip-loc bag and you're off.

item.name: Jupiter Rescue
item.comment: Jupiter Rescue is another one of those co-op we did not enjoy because it never felt like we ever had a chance of winning the game. The enemies just come out too fast to make any head way. On top of that there are the special power cards that bolster your robot's abilities. While they are neat in theory, the game let's you combine some of those card abilities together but does not explain how some of them work in tandem so you are left to figure them out by yourself. There are not a ton of these special abilities so all it would have taken would have been one more page detailing how those abilities combine.

item.name: Kamisado
item.comment: We have only just gotten into playing pure abstract games but this is sure to be a favorite. Looking like a cross between chess and checkers it is neither (fortunately). Each player moves a piece as far forward as he likes either orthagonally or diagonally. Whatever color he lands on decides what piece the other player may move. But all you or your opponent has to do to win is get one piece to the opposite side. So each movement is critical. And in the end, guess what? You are the one who gives your opponent the move to beat you. "YOU beat you!" as the Dice Tower's Zee Garcia put it.

item.name: Kanzume Goddess
item.comment: This game looks fun and has terrific art ( what can i say we are both fans of anime/manga). Tt even has a pretty cool mechanism that allows you to play cards in combination if you've played the right types of symbols. But it doesn't bring enough to keep us interested and plus it doesn't look Japanime games is supporting it all with more content.

item.name: Karate Fight
item.comment: Sigh! More good art. But this game is just the card game war with anime girls slapped on the cards for "theme."

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment: There are not a lot of auction/bidding games that we can get behind just because we loath those mechanics. But here is one we like. This one we tried out as a lark at a demo during the Dice Tower convention. But boy are we glad we did. The similarities between this game and Peleponnes is what drew us in though there are numerous differences. You bid on location tiles to add to your tableau just like Peleponnes but instead of just getting resources , you get to activate abilities on those tiles that benefit you. The art is stylish with iconography that is easy to understand. Not sure if any of the other Key-universe games are for us but this one certainly is.

item.name: Keyflower: Storyteller
item.comment: Not a bad little tile for this game.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: Rolling dice and taking names. That's what it's all about. Will you build up enough energy to power yourself up? Or maybe hang about the outskirts to collect points? Or are you gonna tear your way into Tokyo and demolish everything and everyone? Chances are good you can win using one or all of these methods. Plus you do it all by chucking dice! LOVE IT!Now if it just played better with 2 players. If you just play it with 2 it becomes and back and forth game of "Tokyo is mine! No! Tokyo is mine!"

item.name: King of Tokyo: Halloween
item.comment: Cute and fun, But if you never get it you won't miss anything.

item.name: King of Tokyo: Power Up!
item.comment: This expansion is fun. The idea of now the monsters have their own individual abilities is cool. But we must be honest and say that we enjoy the base game without this much better.

item.name: King's Forge
item.comment: This one is a misfit. Any time we can get a game that's full of dice we typically do so even if we know nothing about it. That's the case with King's Forge. The components are very good , including a 1st player token that must cost $5 to manufacture. Seriously! Don't believe us, look up the game. It's a plastic anvil that's bigger than most tactical mins in WH40K or the like. It's a good theme. But the game is very wonky. There are different factions but no special abilities. Plus the rules are not very well written. Every time we have played it we've had to go to a video tutorial in order to refresh our memories because the rule book is pretty useless. Not so sure this one will hang around much longer. Definitely play it first before buying.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment: Many people have given Kingdom Builder a bad rep. But we just don't see why. Yes it lacks the innovation and strategy of Dominion. But it is still fun for what it is. And that is an abstract strategy game with beautiful art and fairly simple mechanisms. You draw a card and then using the terrain on that card play your houses onto the modular board to the best of your ability. Vaccarino has made a game that you can teach in about 5 minutes (that's how long it took a couple to teach us to play it at Dice Tower Con 2014) but enjoy playing for a very long time.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: This was the first Euro-type game (we have no doubt hardcore Eurogamers will shout at us for even affiliating this game with Euro but whatever) we ever bought and it is still a favorite. Simple and smooth you can roll through this game without spending hours pondering what resources you ought to take to build what structures. The art is fantastic and you cannot go wrong with rolling dice for resources. At least that's our opinion.

item.name: Kingsburg: To Forge a Realm
item.comment: This comes as close to making Kingsburg a 10 as it will ever get. Love the new boards and that you can choose to have buildings other might not have. The leader cards add something to game that was missing before. But the event cards are so not needed that we put them out during set up of our last game and actually totally forgot about them. And the combat chits replace the dice which we think is sacrilege. LOL. But it does make an awesome game even better. If you have Kingsburg then you need "To Forge a Realm" as well.

item.name: Kittens in a Blender
item.comment: This is ... I mean ... It just ... Sorry. I got nothing here. This is just stupid! Do not buy !

item.name: Lagoon: Land of Druids
item.comment: At first glance this games seems quite simple. You are moving your pawns across tiles trying to collect seeds in order to collect points at the end of the game. Also you draw tiles from a bag in order to expand and explore (the bag that comes with this game for drawing the tiles is a joke. If the tiles were Carcassonne size it might work but since the tiles are the size of Keyflower tiles & twice as thick it makes it impossible to shuffles the tiles about in the bag once you put them in)thus giving you and your opponents access to other abilities. However this isn't as easy as it seems. Pawns (called acolytes and Eldrids) can activate other tiles through other pawns as well as having abilities triggered during certain phases of the age,. In the end you are trying to unravel (remove) tiles from play in order to score them at the end of the game. But you score depending on how many of any one type of tile is the most numerous after it's all over. So you have to plan very very VERY carefully. This one brought out our AP more so that even Trajan (and that's saying something). So for real gamers the theme and components may be off putting but this is a very strategic game.

item.name: Lap Dance
item.comment: Ever have one of those moments of weakness where 5 minutes later you are looking at yourself in the mirror and saying, "What is wrong with you?" That happened after we got Lap Dance. The theme is pasted on. The art is terrible. The game play is plodding and even has a times phase with a sand timer. Any time you see a sand timer in a game just walk away. I cannot in good conscience explain why I got this game except that somewhere in the back of my mind the 13 year old boy in the back of my mind giggled and pressed the "buy" button. Please don't make the same mistake I did. Ignore the stupid adolescent voice and just get a good game.

item.name: Las Vegas
item.comment: A simple and easy dice game. You roll dice to try and gain control in a casino to win the money there. Roll your dice ... allocate as many dice of the same number to a casino ... next player ... at the end of a round if you have the most dice at the casino you get the money ... most money wins. Simple but fiendishly fun. Thank you Chaz Marler of Pair of Dice : Paradise. I don't think we would have given this one a second thought if you hadn't talked about in on Board Game Breakfast.

item.name: Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy
item.comment: Now here's a worker placement game with a unique theme. You begin with your family's patriarch/matriarch and slowly build up your family over generations. Make friends, marry off children, invest in the local economy or buy yourself a mansion. Legacy plays smooth and easy even for a work placement game. The theme is what really draws you in and there is more than enough strategy for hard core gamers to latch onto. Be warned however, this thing's footprint on your table will spread larger and larger (especially with 3-4 players) so be prepared for it.

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.comment: The Alien Anthology in a box. Upper Deck delivers an awesome experience in this Alien themed gamed using their deck building system from Marvel Legendary. While it plays similar to Marvel you get a very different feel and the theme is far more immersive. It plays in about the same amount of time but due to the graphic nature of the artwork we wouldn't advise playing this with anyone under 13. Really looking forward to expansions for this. Predators? Prometheus? Sure hope so!

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment: We like Marvel comics and we like deck builders. So this one was a no brainer to get. But the theme just isn't as strong in this one as say Sentinels of the Multiverse though it is actually a better game. But there has been an upswing in the play with this one. Liking it much more with expansions. The only real problem is that it is hard to set this game up randomly like you can with most deck builders because doing it that way you end up with Masterminds involved in schemes that make no sense. Can you see Galactus trying to take over the Daily Bugle?

item.name: Legendary: Dark City
item.comment: This one is great. More heroes. More villains. It just sings is all we can say. Making the base game even more ... dare I say it... Legendary.

item.name: Legendary: Fantastic Four
item.comment: This expansion may have some of the best card interaction of the game so far. A definite must . Plus it gives you the ability to say, "What did I do today? I beat Galactus."

item.name: Legendary: Guardians of the Galaxy
item.comment: If you are planning to get this expansion keep in mind that it doesn't mesh well with the rest of the system because so many (if not all) of the heroes, henchmen and villain use those shard tokens.

item.name: Legendary: Paint the Town Red
item.comment: It's a good expansion but is just too focused on Spider-Man. To the point that some of the cards are hard to compliment with other characters from the base game and expansions.

item.name: Legendary: Secret Wars – Volume 1
item.comment: An awesome expansion for the Legendary system. the only thing keep ing this low is because they included some really obscure characters with it. I mean seriously, how many of you even know who Proxima Midnight is?

item.name: Legendary: Villains – Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment: The powers of the characters in this game are some of the best in Legendary. But the reason it came and went like a thief in the night for use was because of the semi-coop nature. True that in standard Legendary there is technically a winner with whomever has the most points in their victory pile but we never bother with that. Did we defeat the mastermind? Yes. Then we won! But Legendary:Villains pushes this coop game into such a semi-coop with cards that allow you to attack other players, give them bindings and basically try and take it all for yourself. Granted you can try to play it as a full coop but so many of those card abilities are geared towards hammering your opponents. Good idea ( I was really looking forward to playing Magneto finally) but a fail for us.

item.name: Libertalia
item.comment: Ok. Read the card. It does this in this phase. It does this in this phase. Oh and it does this in this phase. Or maybe it does nothing in this phase but oh look what it does in that phase. Wait. Wait. In that phase it does this to you but in this phase it does that to them. I so wanted to like this game but the roundabout roundel nature of the game play had me just inches from flipping my first table. But at least the art is good and that's why it's a 2 and not a 1.

item.name: Livingstone
item.comment: Livingstone is a very well produced game with great art by Michael Menzel and gem pieces that are not your standard fish bowl decorations. It is a simple race game but that is one of its flaws. 1) It really is just a simple race in whcih you play cards to advance a ship along the board. 2) Why it is called Livingstone we have no idea. David Livingstone was a Scottish missionary but nothing about him comes across in the game thematically unless you count his image on the box cover. 3) There is a mechanism in this game that involves putting gold that you've collected into a chest during the game. If at the end of the game you have the least gold in your chest you lose regardless. We are not sure what this mechanism has to do with the theme but as the theme is just pasted on anyway it doesn't matter that much in the long run. However in a 2-player game that mechanism becomes pointless as it can be easily kept up with throughout the game. So it looks good but ... eh.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment: We would have liked this Lord of the Rings game if it had had anything to do with Lord of the Rings.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: Now this game has something to do with Lord of the Rings as you work your way through the world and story of Tolkein's Middle Earth. Spectacular art and intense gameplay make it the best of FF's LCGs and probably one of the better card games in the business. The only thing that keeps it at a 7 is there is too much power creep the further along in the adventures you go. And with that happening the deck you had for that adventure isn't going to work in this adventure. So with each new play we have to remake our decks to have a better chance. Yes. Yes. We know that for some people that retooling of your decks as the story gets more difficult is the best part. But for us it becomes a bit of a chore.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: This is one of our favorite worker placement games. With its easy game play and top rate quality components it should be near the top of everyone's list. But we will say one thing about it. Let's be honest. The D & D theme is pasted on. Don't get us wrong it is still an awesome game despite that. But we have to disagree with certain people (Richard Ham. we're talking to you) who believe this game can get RPGers into board games. We have been part of die hard RPG groups in the past and there is no way they'd consider this D & D. Reasonably certain they would all just look at us in a very cross manner were we to even suggest such a thing.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep: Scoundrels of Skullport
item.comment: Oh yes! This expansion is one of the best. The new locations, lords and intrigue add so much to the game. And the corruption brings out the theme quite well. The new cards and locations all make sense. And did I mention the corruption? This makes the game feel thematic now. Plus now you have new ways to win without just grabbing up quests. New lord cards give you alternate paths to victory. And if you play your cards and meeples right you can pull out an unexpected victory. I started out last in points in my last game but won because the other 2 took so much corruption they lost mondo points while I had gotten rid of all my corruption. If Lords of Waterdeep is a game you own you have to get Scoundrels of Skullport.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: it took us a long time to give this game a try mainly because it has Knizia's name on it and we not liked any of his games so far. But when you hear Tom Vasel talk about a game enough you just have to break down and give it a try. And you know what? It is a very good hand management, set collection game with some really tight strategy. The only thing we don't like about it is that wonky scoring. Add up the numbers on the cards, multiply it by the number of this type of card then subtract 20? It doesn't seem to complicated but we are always having to refer back to the rules and a calculator to see who won. Why does he always have to make scoring in his games so complicated?

item.name: Lost Legacy: Flying Garden
item.comment: Lost Legacy is the spiritual successor of Love Letter but it plays so differently that we never think of the two together in any way. It uses the same basic mechanic : draw a card, play a card. But the way those cards play and the way the end game plays out makes it so much more than just another version of Love Letter. We did fear it might just be a re-theming but its not. Lost legacy is game all its own and worth checking out.

item.name: Lost Legacy: Second Chronicle – Vorpal Sword & Whitegold Spire
item.comment: This edition of Lost Legacy comes down a bit because one of these versions ( The Whitegold Spire) includes scoring points for certain cards and winning that way instead of finding the Lost Legacy. We can understand the designer wanting to step up the game play but we prefer the simplicity of just finding the Legacy.

item.name: Lost Legacy: Third Chronicle – Sacred Grail & Staff of Dragons
item.comment: And they can't all be great. Both these version has some rules that make them more for gamers I guess but we prfer the simplicity of the standard game.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Before a friend of ours basically forced us to try this one during a gaming session (thanks again Bill) you couldn't have payed us to play this thing. 16 cards and some cubes? You're kidding right? Wrong. This game is fun, engaging, fun and wait...did we say fun twice? Oh well. But it is. We don't think you can go wrong with this game whether you get the Tempest version or one of the other editions that are available from AEG. It will be the best $8-10 you have ever spent.

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: FINALLY! We had seen this game played by so many reviewers online but it took so long to get we though it might just be a huge internet/gaming hoax. But it's real! And a very good game to boot. It incorporates many mechanic and styles of play into a small box. It feels like a civilization building game,. plays like a deck builder and works like set collection. A lot of game in a small package. The art is whimsical and the game play is easy to follow. It took a while to get it, but it ain't going nowhere.

item.name: Machi Koro: Harbor Expansion
item.comment: If ratings went above 10 this would get an 11. It makes Machi Koro sooooo much better. Yes. There are new cards but that isn't half of it. The new set up is the best way to play. NO longer do all locations go out. Instead you draw to start until you have at least 10 locations. Some might have just 1 card and you will really want it. And as locations are removed you draw back up to 10 locations. So new locations and opportunities are always coming up. If you have the base game you MUST get the Harbor.

item.name: Machina Arcana
item.comment: Art is cool. The theme looks good. But once you open the rule book it all seems a bit too fiddly. Backed this game on Kickstarter some time back because I didn't see too many other Cthulhu based games besides Fantasy Flight's that we liked. Unfortunately for this game Eldritch Horror came out first and that game does everything I thought Machina Arcana would do and does it better. So this one gets a pass mostly on bad timing.

item.name: Madame Ching
item.comment: The art work and graphic design of this game are very good. The production quality of the components are top notch. But there's something about the game play that has us scratching our head. At its heart madame Ching is a card driven race game with a set collection aspect that makes for an okay game. But not a great one. We wish there was something more to this. But it just doesn't match up to Jamaica which is the best racing game out there.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: You are going to be frustrated. Because this game is hard and complex. Mind you it is still fun. The components are awesome with beautiful artwork on the tiles and well painted minis to boot. But there are just sooooooo many mechanisms you are trying to keep track of. A very slow deck building aspect combined with dice rolling, hand management and host of others. There is even a dummy player for 2-player game (though it isn't as bad in this game and just acts as a timer) There is an exploration aspect to this game that we love as we uncover new locations and enemies. That part we love. But that brings us to the part we loathe. The combat in this game is just too fiddly to keep up with. The rule book even advises you that you should ask other players for help in combat. So Vlaada has made an awesome gamers version of a fantasy adventure game. But maybe we just aren't gamers enough for it.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: Krang Character Expansion
item.comment: see Mage Knight Board Game

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
item.comment: see Mage Knight Board Game

item.name: Maharani
item.comment: Set up it is beautiful to behold. But we just didn't like the see-saw game play. Draw a tile , score gold (otherwise known as points. Why they cal it gold we have no idea. There are no coins. There aren't even score chits. Just a scoring track that , by the way, doesn't show coins or gold either), use gold to play another tile is you scored any gold (otherwise known as points), place a worker, score gold (otherwise known as points), use gold (otherwise known as gold {have I mentioned this before? can you guess that I found it dumb?}) to place more worker to score gold (otherwise known as ... oh you get the idea), then move one to the next player who repeats said process. There's a spinner in the middle fo the board that points to the current player which is a good mechanic but since all the tiles have arrows that show the direction they must be facing to be played and that arrow shifts with the spinner it is just a gimmick. This game is just lather, rinse, repeat and it doesn't do that well. We can clearly see why it came free with the Thebes KS from Queen Games. It just isn't good.

item.name: Mangrovia
item.comment: Mangrovia is a medium weight Euro combining area control with a little worker placement. You are essentially trying to score points my having the majority of your tribe's huts placed in certain areas of the board. You do that using a rondel-type worker placement. As the actions on that "rondel" go around every turn you get one action from one side and another action from the other aside. These actions enable you to build huts, draw cards that are needed to build the huts or rearrange the plots of land in which the huts can be built. There is a grid on the main board where you will score points for having the majority on the X axis and the Y axis. This was purchased at a friendly local gaming store by my wife while she was working out of town. She wanted a different type of Euro and this was suggested. And it was certainly a good suggestion. Not sure if it is getting a big print run anywhere but it you see a copy, give it a try.

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment: The games play is immersive and the mechanics are pretty easy. Two huge problems though. Dungeons crawls such as this require more than just two people to make the experience worthwhile and 90% of the time it is just the two of us. Second are those puzzles. I tell you there is nothing more exciting than exploring a dank cellar complete with an alter and then having to stop the game for 5 minutes while one of our party tries to figure out how to rewire a circuit box. This just takes you totally out of the game. We thought so from the beginning and we're happy to find that one of our favorite game designers thought the same. A good game for some just not for us.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: A fun war game (and we know there are real die hard war gamers screaming at us for calling it such but that's what it is to us)to own. Using the Commands & Colors system (still don't know why it's called that since Battlecry was the first game to use the system) to battle one on one makes for a gaming session we adore. It's simple, elegant and above all fun.

item.name: Merkator
item.comment: From Uwe Rosenburg comes a game with minimal components? Wow! Really? Ok. Granted there are a lot of cubes in this game. But the footprint of this game doesn't take up a whole table. The round goes by quick and players don't sit staring at the board for 10 minutes trying to analyze their next three moves. The time mechanism helps out the players as well as being the game timer. You aren't punished for not doing something and the paths to victory are varied. Merkator is overlooked compared to Agricola and others and we cannot understand why. It's a strong, solid Eurogame. Try it if you haven't.

item.name: Metro
item.comment: Bit of a mess this one. Mechanically and aesthetically. It seems to a Tsuro type of game. You are building circuitous routes on a board using tiles not dissimilar to Tsuro. But whereas Tsuro has larger tiles with routes that are easy to discern, Metro has much smaller tiles with even more twists on them that makes trying to devise any sort of plan vastly too complicated we think. Sure you can play it loose and just lay down tiles without thinking too far ahead but you aren't going to make any useful routes that way. So in order to make any real progress you have to AP yourself into a stupor trying to sort out where to put each and every tile. Not to mention that when you place a tile you might be helping not just yourself but your opponents. This one is just to AP inducing for us.

item.name: Mice and Mystics
item.comment: We love this game. A dungeon crawl with a good theme and a delightful story to back it up. The miniatures in this game were so cool it inspired my wife to take up the hobby of painting minis. Some of the rules can become a bit fiddly and bog down the game play but those incidents are few and far between. The biggest problem we have with it is that "cheese wheel." It can fill up so fast thanks to enemies rolling cheese that we've had to house rule that after each board (both sides) are completed we clear the cheese wheel otherwise we never finish. I'm sure some of you will cry foul but this is the only game we own where we are enjoying playing through the story more than the actual game play.

item.name: Monty Python Fluxx
item.comment: "No expects the Spanish Inquisition!" LOL. Honestly the only reason we don't enjoy this game more is because we haven't ever watched all the movies and shows so we don't get some of the references.

item.name: Morels
item.comment: it's hard to explain what makes this game so fun for us. The game play is simplistic (it's set collection in its simplest form). The art is good. And the theme is ok. But we love playing this as much as any strategic two-players game like say 51st State. It must be that it somehow manages to be greater than the sum of its parts.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: The cute, goofy artwork is nice. But this game is unbridled chaos. We bought it after watching the TableTop episode but found that when actually playing it ... gods! You can barely keep up with it all. Too hectic for us.

item.name: Nefarious: The Mad Scientist Game
item.comment: We are big fans of Vaccarino's games that aren't Dominion. Kingdom Builder is a fun game and yes it is abstract but it never claims to be anything else. Temporum is also a very well designed game with easy game play and good art. So anytime people say that one of his games is bad we tend to scoff. So since everyone said Nefarious was awful we decdided to give this a try especially with a new edition. But in this case everyone is right. This game is awful. It is just what Tom Vasel proclaimed it to. "An economic boring snooze fest." The game play is so simple as to be downright childish. You just do one thing this turn, then pretty much the same thing next turn. Cobble that together with this edition's terrible components (player board that are printed on thin card stock and cards that were so thin I had to actually be constantly mindful of how I was handling them because the slightest crease would bend the bloody things) and this is a really bad game.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment: Ana abstract combat game using hex tiles on a board. the game plays in a unique way in which you play out tiles that will eventually attack your opponent. But each tile will activate in a certain order so you have to plan very strategically. So it is a good game but we really were not into it. Maybe it was it being so abstract but not being a pure abstract.

item.name: New Haven
item.comment: This tile placement, set collection game isn't going to surpass Carcassone (our favorite tile placement game) or Morels (our favorite set collection game) anytime soon but it's still fun. You place tiles to gather resources then use those resources to place other tiles in order to make sets to get points. A cool mechanism is that after you've used all the resources the other players in order get to use what is left over. But the component quality is a bit off, whoever designed the tiles placed in the resource grid apparently neglected to make sure everything was cut right so the more the board fills up the more the tiles are pushed out of line. And the scoring is soooo fiddly. So good but probably could have been better.

item.name: Nightlight
item.comment: Pretty sure this game is broken. The theme is really cool. You play a child's stuffed animals that defend his dreams from nightmares. But the game itself has a lot of problems. First of all the rule book is poorly written. And by rule book I mean a double-sided sheet of paper with rules printed on it. Second, are the stuffed animal characters you fight with. many of them are not very strong except by earning stars that you get in between rounds that allow you to activate toys (weapons) and abilities. The nightmares you fight are not easy ( and while we enjoy a tough co-op, this seems a bit much) so even getting to that is difficult. Except for a stuffed bear that comes with toys(weapons) and abilities already activated. So you pretty much have to use him. Then there is healing. Which is nearly impossible except through the use of another stuffed animal. So you pretty much have to play him. So unless you use these two characters you are pretty much guaranteed to lose. We really wanted to like this game because the theme was so unique. But the game itself ruined that.

item.name: Ninja Dice
item.comment: Production quality is good. However this game just doesn't play well with 2. And since that is the usual number we play at, this one has to be traded.

item.name: Ninja Dice: Location Cards
item.comment: see Ninja Dice.

item.name: Onirim
item.comment: Onirim is ... okay. But just okay isn't enough reason to hold onto it. The theme is cool. You are lost in a dream world and trying to find keys to escape. But the art is ... let's be nice and call it different. And while it plays well as a solitaire game, its 2-player mode is very klunky even for such a small card game.

item.name: Oz Fluxx
item.comment: Some themes shouldn't be made into Fluxx games. Oz just doesn't work.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: This is the game that started it for us. Well, in reality, it was the first episode of TableTop we ever watched. We started watching TableTop when a link to it showed up after a webisode of Felicia Day's FLOG. And we've been board gamers ever since. WHEAAAAAAATOOOOOOON! (Any Big Bang Theory fans out there?) Anyway ... this has to be one of our top 5 games. A thinky adventuresome puzzle that has you sweating from start to finish. You never know what will happen next. Never assume you've won until that last disease is cured! Just when you least expect it Pandemic can leave you a quivering bloody mess (figuratively speaking) on the lab floor. Wash your hands and expect the unexpected.

item.name: Pandemic: In the Lab
item.comment: We've always been able to immerse ourselves in the theme of Pandemic but with In the Lab you feel like you're really working "in the lab" to find the cure to the next great plague. You must have this expansion if you are any kind of fan of the base game.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment: This gets an 8 simply because of the bio-terrorist. This game hardly needs a traitor element to make it better.

item.name: Pandemic: The Cure
item.comment: All the tense game play and co-operative interaction of the regular Pandemic board game are here. But with dice!!Yes this game comes with a huge amount of dice. Dice that are guaranteed to have you screaming "No! Not in Europe! That's an outbreak!" And instead of simply using actions set forth by the rule book you get actions decided by the dice you roll. Fortunately you can re-roll the dice, Yahtzee style, to try and get what you need to save the world. Unfortunately you cannot re-roll those dice when the bio-hazard symbol comes up. That too will have you screaming "Come on!" Don't believe me? watch Rahdo Run Through this one. You will laugh yourself silly at his misfortune. We think the only negative point of The Cure is that the game doesn't let up. In Pandemic you get lulls in the horrific pestilences. Not so in this one. But regardless it is still fun and we think that if you like Pandemic you'll like Pandemic The Cure.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
item.comment: A role-playing game cunningly disguising itself as a card game. We play our copy at home and play another campaign with our gaming group. We cannot get enough of this game. And while it doesn't make us want to play the actual RPG (too many rules) it has gotten us into reading the novels. Cannot wait for the rest of Rise of the Rune Lords then after that is Skulls and Shackles. This is the top notch of games in the business. If you haven't gotten it then you need to.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Character Add-On Deck
item.comment: More characters for Rise of the Rune Lords? Yes please!

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Fortress of the Stone Giants Adventure Deck 4
item.comment: The adventure continues!

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Sins of the Saviors Adventure Deck 5
item.comment: The adventure continues!

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Spires of Xin-Shalast Adventure Deck 6
item.comment: The conclusion draws nigh.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – The Hook Mountain Massacre Adventure Deck 3
item.comment: Even more pathfinder fun.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – The Skinsaw Murders Adventure Deck 2
item.comment: SkinSAW Murders! Not SkinSHAW! Why do so many people say that? LOL. But seriously this is awesome as our Pathfinder adventure continues.

item.name: Pay Dirt
item.comment: Seems almost hard to believe that this came from the designer of Alien Frontiers. Alien Frontiers has simple worker placement and resource management mechanics with a tiny bit of in your face "take that." Pay Dirt however has a somewhat confusing and very limited auction system wherein one person bids on one item in either equipment, personnel or claims. Other players then must bid on that item or pass. So that means if someone bids on say an excavator they want that means you cannot bid on the wash plant you want. or maybe we are totally wrong about that and if that's the case then the rules for the bidding are not very well written. Then there are the hardship cards that just seem to be a massive "take that" element every round of the game. Granted this is a totally different game than Alien Frontiers so you cannot really compare the two. But it just isn't for us for the reasons stated above.

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment: We would never have tried this had a friend not talked us into it one night. Thanks Bill. We steered clear of this because we do not like auction games. But this auction game does something most other auction games doesn't. It plays out like a real auction. If you bid for something but get outbid you don't lose what you bid originally. You get it back. How about that? A realistic auction. There's that and it is also a quick civilization building game that requires some planning and forethought but not so much that it induces mind numbing analysis paralysis. The art on the cards is stylistic and evocative. It's easy to play and it makes you think in a fun way.It's only detriment is that as a two-player game it scales down too much. I'm not sure if that makes sense. With 3 it was great. At 4 it was awesome. But at 2 it was just ok.

item.name: Pergamon
item.comment: Rahdo does it again. After watching Richard Ham's play through of this game we have spent the better part of a year trying to get our hands on it. Finally got it in trade and it was way worth it. Basically a set collection, bidding game. Now normally we don't like bidding games but this one is simple since you just place a marker along a row to try and see how much $$$ you can get to dig up relics from the excavation site. In a two-player game a dummy player vies for $$$ and relics as well but this dummy player system isn't as clunky as the "Free City" in 7 Wonders. Liking it a lot!

item.name: Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League
item.comment: The smallest tightest pick up and deliver game. This games flies so far under the radar that the only reason we had heard of it was through Eric Summerer's Top 100 games of all time on the Dice Tower Network. It's a Kosmos 2-player game with such easy play you can be playing it straight out of the box in 5 minutes. We got this in a trade with several other games and weren't holding out much hope really but since Eric gave it such high marks we thought there was nothing to lose. But we won with this little game.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: "The patriarch of worker placement games" as Sam Healey put it. And he's right. Pillars of the Earth is easily one of the best produced and best designed Euro games you will find. Plus it has the innovation of drawing workers randomly from a bag to see when or if you'll place your worker first or later. Wanna place your worker first? It'll cost you. The sooner you place the more you pay but you get access to what you need sooner. Place later and it won't cost nearly as much but you may get shut out of what you want and have to settle for the left overs. The decision is yours. And as the game goes along you get characters with special abilities to help you out in future rounds. But only if you can get them soon enough. Thus paying more. Pillars plays smooth and clean without any hard to follow rules or fiddly mechanisms. This one is a must own.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Builders Duel
item.comment: So Feld missed with this one. A coin flip to decide a round's outcome? Um....no. But it isn't just that. For such a small game it's fiddly and the rules are not written out very well.

item.name: Pirate Fluxx
item.comment: Once again this Fluxx just doesn't hit the mark for us.

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: So much fun flicking those cars around the track. Seems like it's just crash after crash for us though. It's just a pity that it costs so much. The price really is a bit much. But if you're feel like spending $60-70 on a dexterity game this is the one to get. Wait. Are there any other dexterity games that cost $60-70?

item.name: Praetor
item.comment: We love games set int the theme of Ancient Rome. It is personally my favorite era in history. Now the theme isn't strong in this one but it still pulls you in with the artwork and the mechanics. It feels like a micro-civ game. You build up your part of the city for bonuses and benefits. Rome grows before you adding more and more options. The worker placement system is unique in that you use dice as the workers. Yes. Yes. Dice as workers! That isn't unique! Ah ... but this is the only dice placement game where your workers level up as they work. And when they reach 6 pips they retire. The "pay your people" aspect of the game is a bit annoying ( too much like "feed your people") and some of the tiles are too overpowering but you can easily mitigate that simply by removing said tiles from the game ( I think there are 2. A temple and some market). It's a unique game and well worth the investment.

item.name: Progress: Evolution of Technology
item.comment: You know how in civ-building games there is that tech tree you work on to make your empire better than everyone else's? Is that your favorite part of the game? Then have I got a game for you. Progress is just that. You are building a tech tree. And nothing else. You place cards into your tableau either group use of some type of knowledge you've acquired or by have tech already constructed that meets that card's criteria. And that's really all there is to it. But it is awesome in the respect. We ended getting this game because an oversight in shipping with a previous game earned up us either a refund of the previous game's cost or this game at no charge. Just for giggles we took this. And ti was a good choice. You'll have to pay $$$ for your copy of course. But it will be $$$$ well spent.

item.name: Quantum
item.comment: We often think so many people think that in order for a board game to be good it has to be deep and complex. Quantum is neither of those things and it is quick to become one of our favorites. Love the dice as ships. Mind you any game with dice is a plus for us. Easy game play and variable difficulty. If you want a fun game then Quantum is where it's at.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: DICE! DICE! DICE! There are a lot of them in this box. And it is always so much fun to roll them. Collecting monsters and fighting it out. We just wish this game had a bit more theme in it. We cannot quite put our fingers on what would help that out but we wish we could.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: We were dubious about this one until we watched Rahdo run through it. Then we were hooked. It gives you a sci-fi theme in a brilliantly designed card/hand management game. So interesting to sit there and try to figure out the best way to play your own cards and how to play off your opponents. There is one major problem though and no doubt you can guess what that is if you've played the game. That iconography is physically painful at times trying to figure out what you should be doing. I understand trying to make a game language independent but this one falls way short of success. And with games like Eminent Domain and Star Realms this one is taking a huge dive.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment: We enjoy this expansion mainly because it gives us a way to play solitaire and we don't have many of those. True enough, Arkham Horror can be played solitaire but it takes too long to set up and playing by yourself you WILL lose. LOL. Mind you the robot in Gathering Storm has handed us our heads every time we play thus far but it is still fun.

item.name: The Red Dragon Inn
item.comment: Buy you a drink stranger? No? More's the pity. Care for a round of gambling? What? No? Spoiled sport. Oh for god's sake! Someone get Pooky off that guy's throat! Red Dragon Inn is another of those games that is just too fun not to be played. Granted it's mostly just luck of the draw but in the end it's still fun! And you cannot go wrong with that. Besides in what other game can you share a drink with a priestess and a wizard while living in fear of what the killer bunny is going to do?

item.name: The Red Dragon Inn: Allies – Pooky
item.comment: "Run Away!!!!"

item.name: Dark Gothic: The Forgotten Island Game Supplement
Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: Zee Garcia said it best. "Suffering in a box." It's still a good worker placement style game that draws you into this world of survival, despair and courage. And there is so much replayability. Chances are you're never going to play the game the same way twice. All those event cards to play. Six different adventures from Robinson Crusoe to Indiana Jones to Swiss Family Robinson to cannibal attacks. There are times when it does seem too punishing but that is the challenge don't you know.

item.name: Rococo
item.comment: Never thought we would be able to get into a game about making clothes for the French nobility. This is another one that Richard Ham suckered us into getting (thanks Rahdo)but we have enjoyed it. Don't let the theme put you off. It is a good Euro with area majority, card drafting (buying actually) and resource management. Complex and challenging it can fill a couple hours with a fun game that will surprise you.

item.name: Roll For It!
item.comment: Just roll the dice and take your chances. Roll For It is as simple as it comes. Roll dice to match dice shown on cards. match the dice, you win the card. First person to 40 points wins.

item.name: Roll For It! Deluxe Edition
item.comment: see Roll For It!

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
Roma
item.comment: Roma we picked after getting Arena : Roma II thinking it would be cool to mix and match. But the original doesn't play as well as the sequel.

item.name: Run, Fight, or Die!
item.comment: Me? I usually die. But seriously ... we saw this game on Kickstarter and groaned. Another zombie game? But what we failed to notice was the designer's name. Richard Launius ; the designer of our favorite game Arkham Horror. So when we got to Dice Tower Con 2014 and saw that the man himself was running a demo we gave it a shot. And brother is it FUN! This one could be the king of push your luck games. Fight off the zombies as they come in wave after wave after after wave after wave. Plus you run, fight or die depending on the roll of dice. Always a plus as well. Needless to say when we got back to our hotel room that night we ordered a copy online.

item.name: Run, Fight, or Die! 5/6 Player Expansion
item.comment: see Run, Fight or Die

item.name: Run, Fight, or Die!: Guy Promo Character Board
item.comment: see Run, Fight or Die

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: Seasons is a good game. It gets the rating it does simply because the theme just isn't there. You are wizards trying to summon magic, creatures, etc and prove that you are the best. But I never feel like I am a wizard. I feel like I am rolling dice and using the faces of those dice for actions in the game. That aside it plays good 2-3 (have not tried 4 yet) without much downtime. each round you will get to do something. And while you may not get to do what you really want you aren't shut out of actions. Plus it has delightfully whimsical fantasy art and some of the biggest dice I have ever seen in a game.

item.name: The Secret of Monte Cristo
item.comment: The Secret of Monte Cristo is a good game but it has a flaw in its system when it comes to two-player games. The main mechanic of this game is an action slide on which marbles are placed that determine the order in which players take certain actions. There are four actions that are done each turn (getting supply boats, placing workers in the Chateau D'if, allocating treasure into the Chateau and rearranging the order of either the marbles in the action slide or the gems in the market for scoring) and who gets to perform those actions is determined by whose color marble its at the bottom of that particular slide. It seems straight forward but the rearrange action you can take in the 4th action slide can make the game incredibly swingy. In a 2 player game each player receives 6 marbles as opposed to 4 marbles in a 3-4 player game. In our recent game due to all those marbles being present I managed to rearrange the action slide so that I did all the actions that turn thus blocking my wife from getting a single action. Subsequent to that it meant she could not get a rearrange action until the following turn. That allowed me to also get the first three actions on the next turn again. Yep, if you're doing the math that meant I got 7 straight actions after rearranging. This allowed me to get so many supply boats, workers in the chateau and treasures placed that I won after only 2 scoring rounds and I won by 33 points! Now in a 3-4 players game due to each player only having 4 marbles it will be very difficult to pull off what I did thus making the game not so swingy. But as we play our games 90% of the time 2-player that means this game doesn't work for us. We like games where it is balanced enough that one of us cannot CRUSH the other. And Secret of Monte Cristo doesn't provide that.

item.name: Seeland
item.comment: Richard Ham strikes again! I had seen this online before but never thought anything of it. Building windmills? No thanks. But after watching Rahdo's Run Through we just had to try it. The board is 2-sided allowing you to play an easy version where you see what kinds of crops will be available to help you score. Or there's the other side where the crops are hidden so you aren't quite sure what you'll end up with. Then you have several different modules you can add to up the complexity. Those things combined give it great replayabilty. The graphic design is very well done and once you've finished a game you can see what you've made and feel a little proud.It makes you think without inducing AP for extended periods. This may be one of the best and most underrated Eurogames in the world.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment: It plays well and is not terribly complex in any way. The rounds go by quickly. Though there is a lot of bookkeeping maintaining how many HPs everyone has and what modifiers are attached to whom. But it is full of theme and each character has his/her own story that you can meld into the game play as you like. Repeated plays of this have started to pull it down for us. Unless you play some of the easier villains it can become devastatingly hard. We might have thought before that this game was better than Marvel:Legendary but more plays of both games is changing our mind. While the theme is certainly stronger it may just be a bit too much even for a cooperative game.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Ambuscade Villain Character
item.comment: see Sentinels of the Multiverse.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Infernal Relics
item.comment: see Sentinels of the Multiverse.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City
item.comment: see Sentinels of the Multiverse.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Shattered Timelines
item.comment: see Sentinels of the Multiverse.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Silver Gulch, 1883 Environment
item.comment: see Sentinels of the Multiverse.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: The Final Wasteland Environment
item.comment: see Sentinels of the Multiverse.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Unity Hero Character
item.comment: see Sentinels of the Multiverse.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: A good game all around. The cooperations in this co-op game is brilliant as well as incorporating the traitor element into that cooperation. Each turn you "advance evil" before taking your turn. And there really isn't any action you can take there that isn't going to make you look the traitor. And probably the most brilliant and devious aspect is that there might not even be traitor. Sadly we rarely get a chance to play with more than just the 2 of us or maybe 1 or 2 more. So it's a game that won't see much play time so it's hitting the trade list. But if you get together regularly with 4+ people don't miss this classic in the genre.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: Easy to play and easy to teach. You can takes minutes to understand and hours to enjoy how to play it. The art is whimsical and a joy to look at. It's only issue is that two players seems a bit dry. Much more fun we think with 3-5.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
item.comment: A fun addition to a fun game.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment: Crazy mixed up fun. Alien ninjas. Dinosaurs fairies. It is a good game and we like it but like a few others mentioned previous the 2-player game seems a bit of a let down as the interaction isn't nearly as fun as it could be.

item.name: Smash Up: Awesome Level 9000
item.comment: Love this expansion. Especially the Bear Cavalry. "You're basically borscht."

item.name: Smash Up: The Obligatory Cthulhu Set
item.comment: We have to admit to having a weakness for anything Cthulhu related. But this is just as fun any other Smash Up expansion especially with all the Scooby Doo references.

item.name: SOS Titanic
item.comment: Another good solitaire game. And by that we mean you can play it by yourself and that it is literally the game Solitaire with the theme of Titanic on it. It plays just like you'd expect it to with a few character powers and a game board that it replaced with a spiral bound book that shows the iconic ship slipping beneath the water.

item.name: Splendor
item.comment: This is one of the most well thought out games to be produced in some time. Sure, it isn't mind-blowingly complex or thought=provoking. You collect resources via some poker-style chips and use them to purchase cards from a central display. Those cards add to a permanent set of resources you control that aid in purchasing more expensive cards from the central display again. It is simple but brings out a complex game that moves along at a steady pace and never wears out its welcome. This game should win the Spiel award it has been nominated for. We don't think there is another game out there that plays as smooth and as seamlessly as this one but still brings out so much fun.

item.name: Spyrium
item.comment: Probably the most Euro complexity you can get for your money. Small box. Big game. Worker placement mixed with area majority to give you (possibly) access to locations or special abilities. What's neat is that you place the worker between locations giving you a chance to get something even if what you really wanted gets taken by someone else. So you have quite a bit to think about in that regard. It can be prone to pull AP players into a fugue from time to time however so be wary of that. And except for that is runs like clockwork. A deep complex game in a small package. I do agree with Richard Ham though. Why did they even bother with the "Spyrium" concept. Making this game some weird steam-punk world doesn't really brings anything to it. They could just has easily have mad it about coal mining and it would have been just as good. Maybe Attia didn't want to try and compete with "Coal Baron."

item.name: Star Fluxx
item.comment: This is another one we got thanks to Geek & Sundry's TableTop but we have so much fun with it. Chaotic and almost an out of control game sometimes. Love the theme as well with the mish mash of sci-fi references. Our 2nd favorite Fluxx next to Cthulhu.

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: Yes. Yes. We know. Another deck builder? And a sci-fi themed one at that? Indeed. This one gets high marks for being a simplistic game of attack and recruit. "Core Worlds for Dummies" if you will. We tried Core Worlds before and were totally gob-smacked with how mathy (nope not a word either but you get the idea) it is. The game should come with a calculator. But Star Realms takes the concept of building up forces in your armada/system to attack your adversary and makes it so simple it's almost obscene. LOL. That simplicity and ease of play is what puts it on the same level with Eminent Domain. We don't think you can go wrong with this one.

item.name: Star Realms: BGG Store Promo Set One
Star Wars: The Card Game
item.comment: Here we go again. Another foray into FF's LCG. Call of Cthulhu was a flop. Lord of the Rings wore out its welcome. And you couldn't pay us to try Android : Netrunner. But this has two things going for it. Ease of play and theme. Thank goodness FF hasn't used anything from the prequels yet. Oh please don't do it FantasyFlight! The ease of play comes from how you build the decks. You don't sort through individual cards to make a deck and either A)hope you get the right combos to do well or B) spend days perfecting your deck to destroy everyone. You pick objectives to be used in play and taking the 5 cards corresponding to them. WE LOVE THIS! That individual card selection was what drove us nuts when we used to play YuGiOh! and it's what killed Lord of the Rings. So this set up is so much better. It's only at a 7 because we haven't played it enough. But there is the one problem with it. The committing characters to the Force to tip the Balance of the Force. Ok. We can see the mechanism for it is and respect the strategy it adds to the game. But we so wish it wasn't in there. It just makes the game fiddly in that regard. Alas there seems to be no way to play without it. But we will continue to enjoy it even with that aspect.

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game
item.comment: Always been Star Wars fans (sans Episodes I-III) but not miniatures fans. Thought we might find a happy medium here. But nope. Still hate miniature gaming rules too much to like this one. We did keep the Millennium Falcon mini though.

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – Millennium Falcon Expansion Pack
item.comment: Nope. Not a fan of the X-Wing Minis game. But forever and always a Han Solo fan so I had to have this.

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: One of our favorite worker placement game. Thank you Sam Healey from the Dice Tower for talking so much about this one. Love the theme and the artwork (my dream game room will have Michael Menzel game boards framed and mounted on the walls [I might have mentioned that before] )but most of all the game play. The resource gathering using the dice can be a bit random but it's easy to offset. The one thing we don't like about it is how the scores can go into the 100s. It's just silly really. Why do the scores need to go that high? Our last game ended with a score of 265 to 242. That's insane. But it is the only dent in this otherwise flawless game.

item.name: Sultaniya
item.comment: Art ... good. Game play ... bad.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment: We give it to Plaid Hat games for coming up with an extraordinary 2-player card game that doesn't require you spending hundreds of dollars in an attempt to collect the best cards. Their system of buying those packs and bolstering your own forces is very good. But there is something about this game that niggles us. The most annoying thing is that we can't put my finger on what. It is enjoyable to play but every time we look at it on our shelf we think , "Nah. Rather play something else."

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment: Takenoko is a tile laying game where you move about a hungry panda and a frustrated gardener to try and score points through different means. It's enjoyable and gives you several different ways to win either by precisely laying tiles, growing certain heights and colors of bamboo or by feeding the hungry little panda. The art on the tiles is classic looking and the game play is simplistic without being boring. There's even a collector's edition with a 6" panda and gardener figures and massive tiles. It's $299 but worth it if you really like the game. Myself though (if i was swimming in cash) I would put the collector's edition pieces on display and still play with the standard set.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment: Not so much a game as playing through a huge choose your own adventure fantasy story. There are some gaming mechanics within such as trying to complete goals chosen on cards at the start of the game and throughout. But mostly you are making decisions via multiple choice and hoping that things go well for you. Do you attack the beggar that requests a coin? Do you flirt with the princess that accidentally walks into you in the market? Choose carefully. You never know what might happen. No skill required. Just a decent imagination and about 2+ hours that you'll need to play. Not much of a game truly but still so so so much fun.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Sacred Pool Expansion
item.comment: The expansion here was good for the new characters and cards. But the new ending scenarios just have us befuddled. Who knows? maybe it's just us.

item.name: Talisman (Revised 4th Edition)
item.comment: Granted it is just a roll and move game with simplistic (some might say dull) mechanisms. But we still love playing it for hours. Some times you just want a simple romp through a fantasy world without having to manage your character's mana level or keep track of how damaged your axe has become. It is simplistic but that is what makes it work. We think it is a classic and will continue to enjoy it.

item.name: Tanto Cuore
item.comment: A deck builder with anime maids? Ok. We're in. We love anime/manga and there are just hardly any games out there with that theme. So we pounced on this one as soon as a friend told us about it.Thanks Erich. Lighthearted with just enough strategy to make it engrossing. Though the event cards in the game (bad habits & illness) are just so annoying in game play that we've pulled them out. A bit like Dominion only with theme. Check it out.

item.name: Tanto Cuore: Expanding the House
item.comment: A very nice addition to a very fun game.

item.name: Tanto Cuore: Romantic Vacation
item.comment: Another good addition to this stylish and entertaining little deck builder.

item.name: Temporum
item.comment: Vaccarino comes up with another great game that will no doubt still be overshadowed by Dominion. Cut the man a break. Look past the deck builder and try to judge his subsequent games not by Dominion but by the game itself. Temporum is a game about traveling through time and altering history in order to gain power to lead to victory. As good as the game play is the theme (like Kingdom Builder) isn't there. That said it is still a great game with terrific art, ease of game play and good tactical decisions to be made. Each turn you alter history to change the route through time you travel then play a card. It's as simple as that. Each card allows you to do a few different actions such as gain money, activate a temporary (or permanent) ability or score. The game can be very random and at times it is hard to make a strategy but the before-mentioned ease of game play mitigates this.

item.name: Tentacle Bento
item.comment: Rummy with a very strange twist.

item.name: Terror in Meeple City
item.comment: Rampaging destructive fun and games. Blow a building over. Drop your monster onto a structure to demolish it. Or hurl a bus at your opponent. This is just plain childish fun locked into a board game that has some good mechanisms. At first glance you may think it's a kids game but there is some skill and planning involved. Not much mind you but enough to not make it simply a kid's game. So break it out and go on a RAMPAGE!

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Caverns of Bane
item.comment: You can have your Dominions and Core Worlds. We'll take Thunderstone. This fantasy themed deck builders has captured our imagination since we first heard about via the Dice Tower's Sam Healey. It is awesome.Have to believe it bogs down with more than 2 players but could be wrong. We've only ever played by ourselves. If you only get one deck builder get Thunderstone.

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Numenera
item.comment: Maybe it's just that we know nothing about Numenera. But we cannot get into this one like the rest of Thunderstone Advance. The weird coupling of fantasy and sci-fi just doesn't mesh with us. Plus it isn't an expansion but a stand alone game. Odd.

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Root of Corruption
item.comment: Love all the new cards. But that cooperative adventure where you are laying siege to a fortress has to go.

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Towers of Ruin
item.comment: What's that you say? More Thunderstone Advance? Oh yes, we'll take it.

item.name: Thunderstone: Starter Set
item.comment: More and more cards ... you gotta love it.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: If you are a gamer you have to have Ticket to Ride. That's all we can say. Well, we weren't getting the best use outta this one so we picked up Nordic Countries. But we think this one has a good home as we donated it to a local railway museum.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: A bit more strategic than standard Ticket to Ride with the stations and the tunnels. But just as fun as the original.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment: We enjoyed the original Ticket to Ride but since we were rarely able to play it with three or more players we felt like we were missing out. So we picked up a version designed specifically for 2-3 players and it is awesome. A bit more cutthroat than the original or Europe due to the board size and rail lines. We love this one. Plus the art is even better on this one thanks to the winter theme.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: USA 1910
item.comment: Bigger cards! Thank you Days of Wonder!

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: One of the best exploration themed Euros on the market today. It certainly deserved to win the Spiel des Jahres in 1999. Wish we had known about these kind of board games back then.

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment: Quick, easy and educational. Enough said.

item.name: Tiny Epic Kingdoms
item.comment: This one was up for trade quick. The tiny epic quality of it was very good. Nice components for that little box. But neither of us could really get into the game play. I guess 4X games aren't for us even in a tiny epic format.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: Hero Pack 1
item.comment: see A Touch of Evil : The Supernatural Game.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: Hero Pack 2
item.comment: see A Touch of Evil : The Supernatural Game.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: Something Wicked Expansion
item.comment: see A Touch of Evil : The Supernatural Game.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Coast
item.comment: see A Touch of Evil : The Supernatural Game.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Supernatural Game
A Touch of Evil: Volgovian Nutcracker
Trains
item.comment: We have never played Dominion but this one was described as Dominion with trains. And yes, this is another one that Richard Ham talked us into. Curse that man! But it is an awesome deck builder. It's nice to be able to see your work grow on the board as you use cards to build routes and stations. Plus the artwork is so realistic it has us staring at the cards trying to decide whether it is a photograph or not. Maybe there'll be more of these deck builder with a board type games in the future.

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: Tsuro may be one of our favorite fillers. Place a tile and move your dragon. Pure, simple fun. Though how I ended up in that endless loop I don't know, Did I just break the game or lose?

item.name: Tsuro of the Seas
item.comment: More complex and more fun that standard Tsuro. This time you're running from the dragons. Or trying to at least. And there is something about rolling those dice to see if the dragons are awake. Here dragon dragon dragon.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment: High marks for the educational benefits. But this game just goes to prove that we cannot like games by GMT. Though it is light compared to many of their others it was still too heavy for us.

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment: Our favorite abstract. Granted, we don;y play a lot of abstracts. But this uber-checkers has got to be one of the best.

item.name: Valley of the Kings
item.comment: A good tight, little deck builder. Its just 96 ( I think) cards but it plays easy and has quite a bit of game in there. A pyramid of cards is built and you buy from that adding to a tableau in front of you. Each card taken causes the pyramid to collapse making some items cheaper. Scoring is all about "entombing" artifacts that you have collected. But it just doesn't stack up to other deck builders. Maybe it's the limited number of cards. Maybe it's that the theme just isn't well represented. Maybe we are just used to deck builders being bigger and grander. A good game but just didn't hang around.

item.name: Village
item.comment: Curse you Richard Ham! We never thought we'd ever get into Eurogaming but with each installment of Rahdo Runs Through ... we become more enamored of them. This is well deserved as one of our favorite Euros. The idea of controlling generations of a medieval family is genius and makes for a game that has you thinking from start to finish. Be warned. You are gonna forget that that worker in the blacksmith is about to pass away and try to use him further. You have to to think a few moves ahead in this game. While that is not normally something we like it games here it makes things more entertaining and sometimes even comedic.

item.name: Village Inn
item.comment: Village Inn is a fun expansion. But we're reasonably certain that if you never played or even knew about it, you'd still enjoy Village. It adds a little bit with the Inn cards that grant special abilities and some end game scoring factors. But if we never add it to another play we won't miss it.

item.name: Winter
item.comment: Winter gives a bit more depth of complexity to 51st State. A good addition. Pick one up to add to your copy.

item.name: Yu-Gi-Oh! Trading Card Game
item.comment: We never played Pokemon. We never got into Magic. But YuGiOH! was our addiction some years ago. The TV show hooked us and off we went. Alas now 90% of the cards we had are gone and we've just kept our core decks. If only we could have back all the cash we spent on this game. It was fun and occasionally still is. But clearly the time of Duel Monsters (that's what the game was called in the TV series) has come and gone we think. For us and many others.

item.name: Zero Hour: Survival Horror Card Game
